story:
Thanks to all of you who supported our campaign!

If you still want to contribute to our Event Series or become a Microscope Member, you can do so through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas'  HERE.

The donation is tax-deductible.


ABOUT US

("Optipus" expanded cinema group at Microscope Gallery, July 2014)


Microscope Gallery was founded in the autumn of 2010 by artists and curators Andrea Monti and Elle Burchill and is located in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, NY. We present the works of moving image, sound, digital and performance artists - from the emerging to pioneers of their art forms - through exhibitions and weekly events.

The main motivation for starting Microscope was to address what we consider as an unnecessary divide between the white box setting of the gallery and black box of the screening/performance venue. Microscope was conceived as a place where artists working with these time-based arts can show their works in one or the other or both contexts according to their artistic intent.

Microscope Gallery does essentially two things at once: we operate as a gallery with a regular schedule of exhibitions open five days a week, and alongside we feature a weekly series of events. To date, we have presented 34 art exhibitions and more than 250 events by artists working primarily with film, video, sound, digital art and performance in our current four-hundred-twenty square foot space. 



(From Liz Wendelbo's exhibition "Opticks" at the gallery, 2010)


Through both exhibitions and events, Microscope offers new and emerging artists the opportunity for larger bodies of their works to be seen. We always welcome and consider submissions and offer several Open Call Events each year. Additionally, we strive to gain a wider audience for more established artists and to blur the boundaries between the so-called film-, sound- and performance- worlds – and the "art world".


Microscope Gallery has been featured in many publications in the US and internationally including in Art Observed, ArtFCity, Artforum, Art Review, Blouin ArtInfo, BOMBLOG, BreakThruRadio, Brooklyn Rail, Bushwick Daily, Cinespect, C-Monster, Emergency INDEX, Flavorpill, Huffington Post, Hyperallergic, La Furia Umana, L Magazine, Le Monde, Miami Rail, New York Magazine, Screen Slate, The Los Angeles Times, The London Times, The New York Times, The Village Voice, The Wall Street Journal, TIME Magazine, TimeOut NY, Underground Film Journal, Vice, Visionary Film, WYNC, and many others.



A few quotes about us:

"Most New York galleries today are scenes where people go to show off their clothing style. Microscope isn’t that. It’s a place you go to learn and concentrate on what’s presented to you.” - Ken Jacobs (artist) in NYTimes

“I’d never seen that side of her [Su Friedrich's] as an artist before. These things unrelated to filmmaking managed to illuminate her process as a filmmaker.” -- Sally Berger (curator, MoMA) in NY Times

"I’m really excited by the fervent, steady stream of programming at Microscope gallery in Bushwick. They combine installations and events very nicely in that tiny space, doing a ton with a little. Their curating combines great classic NY avant-garde with new forms of experimentation in projection, music, and sound." -- Rachael Rakes (Film Society of Lincoln Center) in ArtFCity

"I... realized that many of the finest programmers and greatest connoisseurs of the history of cinema are absent from the poll [British Film Institute (BFI)], to which their knowledge could have brought a lot. I'm thinking of Michael Chaiken, Andrea Monti and Elle Burchill from the USA…" -- Nicole Brenez (Cinémathèque Francaise, Paris)

"They say a microscope is an optical instrument to view very small objects, well, as a space Microscope Gallery is a tiny place where great ideas grow larger. Microscope Gallery is great." -- Amos Poe (artist)

"Founded in 2010 in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, Microscope Gallery has rapidly become one of the most interesting art venues in New York." -- Enrico Camporesi (curator, research fellow at Centre Pompidou, Paris) in La Furia Umana

Read "Seen Through The Microscope" a recent interview with Enrico Camporesi for the international journal La Furia Umana

(From "Triple Blind" exhibition, 2013, w/ works by Kenneth Curwood, Bradley Eros, Jeanne Liotta)


WHY WE NEED SUPPORT

We have become very attached to our intimate space, as have many of you. But in order to continue to present the quality of events programming that Microscope aspires to it is time to expand in both size and scope.

We are extremely pleased to share with you that we just signed a long-term lease on a great two-thousand square foot, semi-raw warehouse space.

It is still in Bushwick, but more conveniently located, right off the Jefferson L train stop.


The move will make it possible to present many types of Events that we were previously unable to do and to bring larger shows in-house, such as our "now what" moving image and performance series curated through an international Open Call.

In order to move forward, we are asking for and will need your generous support.


USE OF FUNDS

Between now and our planned opening this September, there is a lot of work to be done in order to house the Event Series.

By contributing to our Indiegogo Campaign you will help us cover the costs of a quiet air conditioning/heating system, building and soundproofing walls, skylight covers as well as upgrading our equipment for a larger venue including a 12-foot screen, stronger speakers, longer-throw projectors, additional seating, and other essential costs.



Your contributions will also help make it possible for us to run an expanded Event Series in which we will be extending our outreach, working with additional curators, increasing our film rental budget and involving others in the day-to-day operations such as promotion, web, archiving, and video documentation of the new series.

Please note that a portion of your donations will be given to the artists who generously made available their works for the campaign, including Bradley Eros, Anton Perich, Sarah Halpern, Su Friedrich, Kevvy Metal, Julian Glander, Cave Days, Liz Wendelbo, Peggy Ahwesh, James Fotopoulos, Jack Smith, Takahiko Iimura, Marni Kotak, and Jonas Mekas.


TAX-DEDUCTIBLE

Donations to our Indiegogo Campaign are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas.


REWARDS

AMONG THE MANY GREAT REWARDS WE HAVE TO OFFER YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT ARE:

Microscope Tote Bag
Our new Microscope Tote Bag, featuring a xerox collage by artist Bradley Eros.


Special Video #1: "Taylor Mead Skype Performance"
Private link to the full 30-minute long Skype performance by New York legend Taylor Mead that took place at Microscope in occasion of his participation to the Berlin-based Festival Camp/Anti-Camp!


Special Video #2: "Moving Image Moving Forward" Panel Discussion
Private link to the full video document of the panel discussion "Moving Image Moving Forward" organized by Microscope for Moving Image New York 2014. Panelists: Christiane Paul (curator, Whitney Museum), Jonas Mekas (artists), Ed Halter (co-founder, Light Industry), Leslie Thornton (artist), Elle Burchill (Microscope Gallery), moderated by Alice Gray Stites (curator, 24c Museum). A very intense hour-long discussion on the state of moving image!


"Blackbird" Booklet by Sarah Halpern
Signed booklet by artist Sarah Halpern, 2013, 7 x 5.5", pp. 19

Halpern revisits classic Hollywood films through xeroxed collages and shadow plays made with cut-outs of images from film theory books and movie fan magazines. The booklet is inspired by the artist’s discovery of “The Film Classic Library” – a series of complete re-constructions of Hollywood movies in book form – from which she has appropriated, among others, images of Humphrey Bogart and Mary Astor starring in John Huston’s “The Maltese Falcon”. Freeing these references from the confines of character and plot structure, Halpern creates a layered conversation concerning film iconography and male/female relationships.


"Gently Down The Stream" Booklet by Su Friedrich
Handmade booklet by artist Su Friedrich, 1995, 3 x 9", pp. 36
A signed booklet made by Su Friedrich in 1995 using images and text from her great 1981 film "Gently Down The Stream".

From the booklet:
"I make a second / vagina / beside my first one / I look in surprise
Which / is the original?"

About the film:
"Gently Down the Stream can be described about as easily as you can hold on to a handful of water....Suffice it to say that Friedrich has an artist's instinctive sense of film—she expresses herself in it with a freedom and rightness that strike the viewer immediately. When the last image leaves the screen, you may not be able to say what you've seen, but you know what you've felt."
—Stuart Klawans, THE NATION


VHS Tape Edition "MONOBROW #1"
compiled by Kevvy Metal and Julian Glander, 2013

Monobrow VHS is a VHS tape publication, run by Julian Glander and Kevvy Metal in Brooklyn, which features contemporary artists working in film, video, and animation.

Contents of the first volume:
- Bobby Abate, Kitty's Nite In (1995, 2 min 55 sec)
 - Dark Igloo, Sans Crap (2012, 1 min 23 sec) 
- Emily Pelstring, Skeleton Dance (2011, 2 min 11 sec) 
- Helena Frank, Heavy Heads (2010, 7 min 39 sec) 
- Helmut Smits, About 20 Times Slower than a Sunset (2012, 1 min 11 sec) 
- Jodie Mack, Unsubscribe #4: The Saddest Song in the World (2010, 2:51 min) 
- Josh Kline, Camera Attack (2000, 4 min, 9 sec)
 - Jules Guérin, BANG!, MAD, and Chaosmos (2012, animation loops, 5 sec) 
- Julian Glander and Kyle Sauer, Turtle Trouble in Tiny Town (2012, 1:05 min)
 - Juliet Phillips, O! (2012, 1 min 12 sec) 
- Kevvy Metal, U No U Wnt 2 Kiss ME (2013, 3 min 3 sec) 
- Michael Robinson, All Through the Night (2008, 4 min (20 sec)
 - Sabrina Ratté, Data Daze (Music video for Le Révélateur) (2012, 3 :32 min) 
- Tara Nelson, Beautiful Secrets (2010, 7 min 34 sec) 
- Timothy Fiore, Baby (Music video for The Babies) (2012, 2 min 59 sec)
 - Tim Lahan, Passing Time (2011, 22 sec)
 - Yoshi Sodeoka, Psychedelic Death Vomit (Slight Return) 3d (2010, 4 :21 min)


CAVE DAYS' Limited Edition 10" Vinyl "Memoriam"

Cave Days' second EP "Memoriam" (December 2013) features 4 tracks previously unreleased. It is issued as a purple, translucent, 45rpm, 110 gram vinyl. Graphics by Troy Odell, limited to 250.

Includes immediate download of 4-track album in the high-quality format of your choice (MP3, FLAC, and more). More info at cavedays.bandcamp.com


"Bolex Paillard" Booklet by Liz Wendelbo
Signed Booklet by artist Liz Wendelbo, 2010, 6 x 4 inches, 20 pp.

This book accompanies 'Opticks', 16mm films by Liz Wendelbo that were premiered at the New Museum NY, for a Xeno & Oaklander show in November 2011. It features appropriated bondage imagery juxtaposed with illustrations from the artist's Bolex 16mm camera instruction manual.

'Bolex Paillard' book, laser print, ed. 100, by Liz Wendelbo and Nathan Antolik
READ MORE: Liz Wendelbo talks about her work in ARTFORUM 

"Eisenstein's Library" Book by Peggy Ahwesh
Signed book by artist Peggy Ahwesh, 2011, 7 x 9 inches, 26 pp.

"Keith Sanborn and Masha Godovannaya were meeting with the famous Eisenstein scholar Naum Kleiman to discuss some research they were doing and we met at an apartment in Moscow where Eisenstein's widow lived after his death. It is a classic example of the 'apartment museums' that are popular throughout Russia but this one open only by invitation. It became the repository of the remains of Eisenstein's library and even if fragmentary, is a great indicator of his vast knowledge of literature and languages and his interest in high and low culture in addition to leaving a trace of the research he did for his film subjects and techniques.  The Ernest Fenollosa volume for example was an important reference for the development of the theory of montage. Naum and the others talked for hours and I spent that time studying the books.  The place had no electricity so by the end I was photographing individual volumes near the open window as the light faded. " - PA


Mysteries Books 1, 2, & 3 by James Fotopoulos
3 Signed books by artist James Fotopoulos, 2009, 5.5 x 8.5 inches, 39 pp.

Mysteries 1 - "Clues", 9 pp.
Mysteries 2 - "Nuances", 11pp.
Mysteries 3 - "The Details of Horror", 19pp.

"The Mysteries Books are a result of several months of phone conversations with a Long Distance Friend. During these calls I picked up on Clues that revealed my Friend’s Character. These are complied into Book 1: Clues.  While I was collecting these Clues many of my Friend’s Nuances became apparent.  Which consist of Book 2: Nuances.  Finally, these conversations contained many Details  - all of which we both found horrifying.  They can be found in Book 3: The Details of Horror." - JF


"AFTER THE FACT" Booklet by Tim Geraghty
Signed booklet by artist Tim Geraghty, 2013, 8.5 x 8.5 inches, 40 pp.

A collection of images from photographs, film slides and stills by Tim Geraghty.

Tim Geraghty is an artist working in film and video from Providence, Rhode Island, currently living in Brooklyn, New York. He’s a professional broadcast news and documentary editor interested in radically re-editing footage, especially found footage from his line of work, into films with the associative language of dreams. He has previously exhibited his works at Anthology Film Archives, Issue Project Room, Microscope Gallery, White Box, SCOPE NY, Lincoln Center, SUDLAB (Naples) and the Rotterdam International Film Festival.


"N'arrosez pas sur une flamme nue" (Do not spray on an open flame)
Xerox Collage by Bradley Eros
Signed xerox collage by artist Bradley Eros, 2014, 11 x 14 inches, ed. of 20

BRADLEY EROS is a Brooklyn-based artist working in multiple mediums. His works have exhibited and screened extensively in the US and abroad including at The Whitney Biennial, The Whitney Museum’s series The American Century, MoMA, The Andy Warhol Museum, MoMA PS1, Camden Arts Center (London), Anthology Film Archives, Arsenal (Berlin), Participant Inc., The Kitchen, Performa09, Exit Art, White Box, LMAK Projects, and The New York, London and Rotterdam Film Festivals. Collaborations include the Alchemical Theater, the band Circle X, Voom HD Lab, and the expanded cinema groups kinoSonik, Arcane Project and currently Optipus.


"Untitled (Mousepad)" by Kevvy Metal
Signed Mousepad by artist Kevvy Metal, 2014, 1/4 inch thick foam mousepad, 9.25 x 7.75 inches, ed. of 50

KEVVY METAL is a Brooklyn-based filmmaker, media artist, and curator born in Western New York. He graduated in 2012 from Boston University in Film and Philosophy. He is also a co-founder of the VHS tape publication MONOBROW. 


1969 Film-makers Catalogue w/ cover design by Jack Smith
"Film-makers Lecture Bureau Catalogue No. 1", 1969, 70 pp., cover design by Jack Smith

From the introduction:
"The Film-makers Lecture Bureau was formed to service the constantly growing requests for personal appearances of independent filmmakers at colleges, universities and film societies. In the past few years this demand has increased so much that it has been necessary to gather under one cover those filmmakers who have consented to appear as lecturers with their films. Represented in this catalogue also are film scholars and historians and film laboratory technicians."


"Circle & Square" video by Takahiko Iimura
"Circle & Square", dvd, color, sound, 2011, 6 minutes, signed

A rare dvd edition of Takahiko Iimura's performance "Circle & Square" that took place at Microscope in 2011. A video document by Takahiko Iimura.

About the performance:
"A black film leader pierced with holes is what we see when looking at the filmstrip today. What the audience saw, when it was incorporated into a performance, was something quite different. The filmstrip was looped through a hook in the ceiling and into a film projector at the back of the room. On the screen, circles of white light appeared as Iimura perforated the filmstrip with a hole puncher. The clicking sounds produced by the hole-punching operation could be heard over the buzzing of the projector. The white circles accumulated as the performance continued until finally Iimura punched one hole too many, and, after a final spin around the room, the filmstrip fell to the floor, leaving a white square on the screen at the front. - Julian Ross, MoMA Post


"AI (LOVE)" video by Takahiko Iimura
"AI (Love)", dvd (video transfer from 16mm film), b/w, sound, 1962, 10 minutes, signed

A rare dvd edition of Takahiko Iimura's influential 1962 film "AI" with a special soundtrack by Yoko Ono.

"I first saw Iimura's film "LOVE" in 1962 in Tokyo. I was very impressed by the poetic and sensuous, yet experimental, direction of the film and did the sound for it. " -- Yoko Ono, 1996

"I have seen a number of Japanese avant-garde films at the Brussels international Experimental Film Festival, at Cannes, and at other places. Of all those films, Iimura's LOVE stands out in its beauty and originality, a film poem, with no usual pseudo-surrealist imagery. Closest comparison would be Brakhage's LOVING or Jack Smith's FLAMING CREATURES. LOVE is a poetic and sensuous exploration of the body…fluid, direct, beautiful" - Jonas Mekas, 1966


Special Print by Takahiko Iimura
Takahiko Iimura, "Legs", 1970, b/w photographic print, 15.5 x 11.5 inches, ed. of 20, signed

A rare print by Takahiko Iimura featuring a shot of "legs" in 3 consecutive frames from his 16mm film AI (LOVE).


Limited-edition Towel by artist Marni Kotak
Marni Kotak, "Moon Tide", 2011, Microfleece Ribbed Towel, 27 x 57 ", ed. of 20

Marni Kotak is a performance artist who makes multimedia works in which she presents an everyday life being lived. In October 2011, she gave birth to her son as a live performance in her durational exhibition, The Birth of Baby X, at Microscope Gallery in Brooklyn, NY. Kotak’s other Found Performances, or works based on daily activities, experiences, or accomplishments, include Calorie Countdown (2013), Raising Baby X (ongoing), Postpartum Depression (2012), and staged re-enactments of her own birth, attending her grandfather’s funeral and losing her virginity in a blue Plymouth. Her work has been featured in national and international media such as the New York Times, Washington Post, Good Morning America, TIME, The Village Voice, Hyperallergic and the Times of London. She received a BA from Bard College and an MFA from Brooklyn College and is represented by Microscope Gallery in Brooklyn, New York.



Rare signed dvd edition of "Birth of a Nation" by Jonas Mekas
"Birth of a Nation" (1997), a film by Jonas Mekas, 16mm to video, color, sound, 85 min

One hundred and sixty portraits or rather appearances, sketches and glimpses of avant-garde, independent filmmakers and film activists between 1955 and 1996.

"Why BIRTH OF A NATION? Because the film independents IS a nation in itself. We are surrounded by commercial cinema Nation same way as the indigenous people of the United States or of any other country are surrounded by Ruling Powers.

We are the invisible, but essential nation of cinema. We are Cinema." - Jonas Mekas


Special Print by Jonas Mekas
"Burroughs", 2014, ink-jet archival print, 17 x 11", ed. of 3

A rare new print by Jonas Mekas portraying William Burroughs during a reading at St. Mark's Church in ca. 1975. Only Edition 1 is available!


Artist Portraits 1971-73: rare b/w photographs by Anton Perich
Signed silver gelatin prints by artist Anton Perich, 2011, 10 x 8 inches, ed. of 25

Willem De Kooning (Max's Kansas City, NY, 1972)

Shirley Clarke (NYC, 1971)

Lou Reed (NYC, 1971)

John Chamberlain (Chelsea Hotel, NY, 1972)

John Waters (Max's Kansas City, NY, 1973)




PHILOSOPHY

It is important to know that the philosophy of the Event Series will not change. Microscope will continue to show films, videos, analog and digital art, performance art, visual and sound programs and readings. Artists from the emerging to pioneers, emphasizing the new, with the artist present.

We want to continue to make visible the unseen, to represent the underrepresented  - be it a neglected side of a known artist's body of work, or the fresh accomplishments of a young artist who has not yet had a first show. To get from now to the moment where the lights go off on our first event, we need your help! This is the only way we can continue, and grow.

 
Sincere THANKS to all of you who have supported us thus far!
story_txt:
Thanks to all of you who supported our campaign!If you still want to contribute to our Event Series or become a Microscope Member, you can do so through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas'  HERE.The donation is tax-deductible.ABOUT US("Optipus" expanded cinema group at Microscope Gallery, July 2014)Microscope Gallery was founded in the autumn of 2010 by artists and curators Andrea Monti and Elle Burchill and is located in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, NY. We present the works of moving image, sound, digital and performance artists - from the emerging to pioneers of their art forms - through exhibitions and weekly events.The main motivation for starting Microscope was to address what we consider as an unnecessary divide between the white box setting of the gallery and black box of the screening/performance venue. Microscope was conceived as a place where artists working with these time-based arts can show their works in one or the other or both contexts according to their artistic intent.Microscope Gallery does essentially two things at once: we operate as a gallery with a regular schedule of exhibitions open five days a week, and alongside we feature a weekly series of events. To date, we have presented 34 art exhibitions and more than 250 events by artists working primarily with film, video, sound, digital art and performance in our current four-hundred-twenty square foot space.  (From Liz Wendelbo's exhibition "Opticks" at the gallery, 2010)Through both exhibitions and events, Microscope offers new and emerging artists the opportunity for larger bodies of their works to be seen. We always welcome and consider submissions and offer several Open Call Events each year. Additionally, we strive to gain a wider audience for more established artists and to blur the boundaries between the so-called film-, sound- and performance- worlds – and the "art world". Microscope Gallery 
has been featured in many publications in the US and internationally 
including in Art Observed, ArtFCity, Artforum, Art Review, Blouin 
ArtInfo, BOMBLOG, BreakThruRadio, Brooklyn Rail, Bushwick Daily, 
Cinespect, C-Monster, Emergency INDEX, Flavorpill, Huffington Post, 
Hyperallergic, La Furia Umana, L Magazine, Le Monde, Miami Rail, New 
York Magazine, Screen Slate, The Los Angeles Times, The London Times, 
The New York Times, The Village Voice, The Wall Street Journal, TIME 
Magazine, TimeOut NY, Underground Film Journal, Vice, Visionary Film, 
WYNC, and many others.A few quotes about us:"Most New York galleries today are scenes where people go to show off their clothing style. Microscope isn’t that. It’s a place you go to learn and concentrate on what’s presented to you.” - Ken Jacobs (artist) in NYTimes“I’d never seen that side of her [Su Friedrich's] as an artist before. These things unrelated to filmmaking managed to illuminate her process as a filmmaker.” -- Sally Berger (curator, MoMA) in NY Times"I’m really excited by the fervent, steady stream of programming at Microscope gallery in Bushwick. They combine installations and events very nicely in that tiny space, doing a ton with a little. Their curating combines great classic NY avant-garde with new forms of experimentation in projection, music, and sound." -- Rachael Rakes (Film Society of Lincoln Center) in ArtFCity"I... realized that many of the finest programmers and greatest connoisseurs of the history of cinema are absent from the poll [British Film Institute (BFI)], to which their knowledge could have brought a lot. I'm thinking of Michael Chaiken, Andrea Monti and Elle Burchill from the USA…" -- Nicole Brenez (Cinémathèque Francaise, Paris)"They say a microscope is an optical instrument to view very small objects, well, as a space Microscope Gallery is a tiny place where great ideas grow larger. Microscope Gallery is great." -- Amos Poe (artist)"Founded in 2010 in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn, Microscope Gallery has rapidly become one of the most interesting art venues in New York." -- Enrico Camporesi (curator, research fellow at Centre Pompidou, Paris) in La Furia UmanaRead "Seen Through The Microscope" a recent interview with Enrico Camporesi for the international journal La Furia Umana(From "Triple Blind" exhibition, 2013, w/ works by Kenneth Curwood, Bradley Eros, Jeanne Liotta)WHY WE NEED SUPPORTWe have become very attached to our intimate space, as have many of you. But in order to continue to present the quality of events programming that Microscope aspires to it is time to expand in both size and scope.We are extremely pleased to share with you that we just signed a long-term lease on a great two-thousand square foot, semi-raw warehouse space.It is still in Bushwick, but more conveniently located, right off the Jefferson L train stop. The move will make it possible to present many types of Events that we were previously unable to do and to bring larger shows in-house, such as our "now what" moving image and performance series curated through an international Open Call. In order to move forward, we are asking for and will need your generous support.USE OF FUNDSBetween now and our planned opening this September, there is a lot of work to be done in order to house the Event Series.By contributing to our Indiegogo Campaign you will help us cover the costs of a quiet air conditioning/heating system, building and soundproofing walls, skylight covers as well as upgrading our equipment for a larger venue including a 12-foot screen, stronger speakers, longer-throw projectors, additional seating, and other essential costs.Your contributions will also help make it possible for us to run an expanded Event Series in which we will be extending our outreach, working with additional curators, increasing our film rental budget and involving others in the day-to-day operations such as promotion, web, archiving, and video documentation of the new series.Please note that a portion of your donations will be given to the artists who generously made available their works for the campaign, including Bradley Eros, Anton Perich, Sarah Halpern, Su Friedrich, Kevvy Metal, Julian Glander, Cave Days, Liz Wendelbo, Peggy Ahwesh, James Fotopoulos, Jack Smith, Takahiko Iimura, Marni Kotak, and Jonas Mekas.TAX-DEDUCTIBLEDonations to our Indiegogo Campaign are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas.REWARDSAMONG THE MANY GREAT REWARDS WE HAVE TO OFFER YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT ARE:Microscope Tote BagOur new Microscope Tote Bag, featuring a xerox collage by artist Bradley Eros.Special Video #1: "Taylor Mead Skype Performance"Private link to the full 30-minute long Skype performance by New York legend Taylor Mead that took place at Microscope in occasion of his participation to the Berlin-based Festival Camp/Anti-Camp! Special Video #2: "Moving Image Moving Forward" Panel DiscussionPrivate link to the full video document of the panel discussion "Moving Image Moving Forward" organized by Microscope for Moving Image New York 2014. Panelists: Christiane Paul (curator, Whitney Museum), Jonas Mekas (artists), Ed Halter (co-founder, Light Industry), Leslie Thornton (artist), Elle Burchill (Microscope Gallery), moderated by Alice Gray Stites (curator, 24c Museum). A very intense hour-long discussion on the state of moving image! Kotak’s other Found Performances, or works based on daily activities, experiences, or accomplishments, include Calorie Countdown (2013), Raising Baby X (ongoing), Postpartum Depression (2012), and staged re-enactments of her own birth, attending her grandfather’s funeral and losing her virginity in a blue Plymouth. Her work has been featured in national and international media such as the New York Times, Washington Post, Good Morning America, TIME, The Village Voice, Hyperallergic and the Times of London. She received a BA from Bard College and an MFA from Brooklyn College and is represented by Microscope Gallery in Brooklyn, New York.Rare signed dvd edition of "Birth of a Nation" by Jonas Mekas"Birth of a Nation" (1997), a film by Jonas Mekas, 16mm to video, color, sound, 85 minOne hundred and sixty portraits or rather appearances, sketches and glimpses of avant-garde, independent filmmakers and film activists between 1955 and 1996."Why BIRTH OF A NATION? Because the film independents IS a nation in itself. We are surrounded by commercial cinema Nation same way as the indigenous people of the United States or of any other country are surrounded by Ruling Powers.We are the invisible, but essential nation of cinema. We are Cinema." - Jonas MekasSpecial Print by Jonas Mekas"Burroughs", 2014, ink-jet archival print, 17 x 11", ed. of 3A rare new print by Jonas Mekas portraying William Burroughs during a reading at St. Mark's Church in ca. 1975. Only Edition 1 is available!Artist Portraits 1971-73: rare b/w photographs by Anton PerichSigned silver gelatin prints by artist Anton Perich, 2011, 10 x 8 inches, ed. of 25Willem De Kooning (Max's Kansas City, NY, 1972)Shirley Clarke (NYC, 1971)Lou Reed (NYC, 1971)John Chamberlain (Chelsea Hotel, NY, 1972)John Waters (Max's Kansas City, NY, 1973)PHILOSOPHYIt is important to know that the philosophy of the Event Series will not change. Microscope will continue to show films, videos, analog and digital art, performance art, visual and sound programs and readings. Artists from the emerging to pioneers, emphasizing the new, with the artist present.We want to continue to make visible the unseen, to represent the underrepresented  - be it a neglected side of a known artist's body of work, or the fresh accomplishments of a young artist who has not yet had a first show. To get from now to the moment where the lights go off on our first event, we need your help! This is the only way we can continue, and grow.  Sincere THANKS to all of you who have supported us thus far!

story:
Hello, my name is Tod Gunter. I'm a self-employed designer and illustrator. I've had a life-long interest in aviation, and I create aircraft art in my spare time.


I started selling my art online in 2001 as a part-time business, called PlaneGrafx. Four years later, I was invited to an air show in CT, where my art was made the official souvenir. The show was focused on one type of airplane, a World War II fighter called the Corsair. It was manufactured in Bridgeport, and the air show celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of the Corsair's creation. I offered eight renderings of the airplane, and I did pretty well over the course of the three-day show.


Since then, I have started several other illustrations, but finding enough time to complete the artwork has been challenging. My primary occupation as a designer keeps me busy, along with life in general.


One of my goals for 2012 is to complete the artwork I am currently working on. I would like to transform my part-time business into a full-time venture, but I need to offer a variety of renderings in order to make the business viable.


That's where your sponsorship comes in. With your support, I plan to complete a series of renderings at a time, and build an inventory of art that will eventually make my business self-sustaining. I have five airplanes in various stages of completion, and if I am successful with raising money to finish the first aircraft, I will have additional campaigns to fund each of the remaining four.


The first illustration I want to finish is a series of the F-4 Phantom, which was flown in the Vietnam War. I have been working on two versions: one flown by the U.S. Navy and Marines, and another by the U.S. Air Force. The Navy and Marine version will be rendered in a variety of color schemes from different squadrons, including the Blue Angels. The Air Force model will be painted in jungle camouflage.


ABOUT THE ART


All of my illustrations are extensively researched to ensure accuracy, and that's a time consuming process. Typically, the base airplane rendering takes about 3 to 4 months to complete, working full-time. There's about 2 month's worth of work remaining on the Phantom series, which will result in several pieces of art I can offer.


I create all of my work on a computer, but I render everything by eye. I use two applications, Adobe IllustratorÂ®, and Adobe PhotoshopÂ®. The prints I sell are gallery-quality, signed and matted, and are ready to frame.


To see more of my artwork, visit my website: www.planegrafx.com.


WHAT I NEED AND WHAT YOU GET


My goal is to raise $7,500, so I can complete the Phantom series of illustrations. If I am able to raise the full amount, the artwork will be finished within two months of funding. Getting the Phantom done is critical to my dream of establishing a full-time business selling my work. The money I raise will be in lieu of the income I'd normally bring in as a freelance designer. This will allow me to dedicate two months of my time to 'Phinish the Phantom.'


Naturally, if the full amount isn't raised, then I will have to change the timetable as to when I expect the art to be done--but work on it will continue, nevertheless.


I'm not expecting something for nothing. Everyone who sponsors 'Phinish the Phantom' will be rewarded for their contribution. Check out what I'm offering for perks--there's some pretty cool stuff!


I hope you'll spread the word to your own networks about this campaign, using the share tools! Thanks in advance for your help, and please sponsor this project!

story:
The Bureau of Self-Recognition is a conceptual art project that I've been engaged in since October of 2011. I've received a lot of support for the project: I've shown aspects of it at the Culture Project's Women Center Stage Festival, Agape Enterprise, IV Soldiers, Queens Media Arts Development's ITINERANT performance festival, and EIDIA House/Plato's Cave, among other places. I've worked with more than 20 "clients" through the Free Consultations program, signed up more than 50 account holders for the Bank of Self-Recognition, and had photographs from various phases published online, alongside some process-based writing.

Now I'm gearing up for the biggest phase thus far: a solo exhibit of the entire project at Momenta Art, which is scheduled to open on May 31st. In conjunction with the exhibit, I'm working with Jessalyn Wakefield and am i human Press to create a limited edition artist's book for the project. It's an 8" x 8", full-color, hardcover, beautiful object that details the Bureau of Self-Recognition's journey through three main reflections: first the self, then the self and a single other, and finally the self and the community.

Both of these important works are definitely happening. The only question is how. I need help to pay for aspects of printing and shipping the book, as well as to finance transport of elements for the exhibition.

I've been incredibly successful in galvanizing an engaged audience for this project. Now I'm just asking you for a small amount of financial support. See below for the list of rewards I'm offering, which range from a Bureau of Self-Recognition postcard to a signed copy of the book and a piece of original artwork. Any contribution helps.

Want to know more? Check out the Bureau of Self-Recognition project blog, or visit my portfolio website, where you can see more about me and the other work that I make, and how the Bureau fits into my practice.

 

Who should support this project? 

Anyone who likes conceptual art, performance, investigations of the everyday (or daily life and behavior), anyone who's interested in archival manifestations of experiential projects, anyone who takes photos, wonders what his or her life looks like over time, or anyone who's curious. It's my goal to give you rewards that don't just thank you for your contribution: each object or text will be your own "in" to the project itself. This is an invitation.

 

Where will the money go?

The first $1,100 (roughly) will go towards printing of 50 copies of the Bureau of Self-Recognition book. The rest will be used in support of elements for the exhibit, which I'm happy to detail more specifically for anyone who's curious. Just email me.

In truth, this project will cost much, much more than the $2,000 that I'm asking for here. All of my plans would not be possible without the amazingly dedicated free and low-cost labor that I've received from talented professionals in support of this work. The more I raise here, the more likely it is that I will be able to offer even token compensation for other people's efforts.

 

Who am I? Here's my bio.

Chloë Bass is an artist and public practitioner. Upcoming solo exhibit: The Bureau of Self-Recognition, Momenta Art, 2013. Chloë has received commissions from the Culture Project’s Women Center Stage Festival, the Bushwick Starr’s Bushwhack Festival, and 3rd Ward’s Moviehouse. Recent artistic work has been seen at Exit Art, Contemporary Art Institute of Detroit, ITINERANT Performance Festival, Glasshouse, Panoply Performance Laboratory, SCOPE Art Fair, Fountain Miami, Agape Enterprise, and the New Museum’s Festival of Ideas for the New City. She is a 2011 & 2012 Rema Hort Mann Foundation Individual Artist Grant Nominee. From 2007 – 2011, Chloë served as the co-lead organizer for Arts in Bushwick, which produces Bushwick Open Studios, BETA Spaces, and Armory Arts Week performance festival SITE Fest, which she founded. She has guest lectured at Parsons School of Design, Sotheby’s Institute, the Polytechnic University of Puerto Rico, and Brooklyn College CUNY. She holds a BA from Yale University, and an MFA in Performance and Interactive Media Arts (PIMA) from Brooklyn College. She is an Adjunct Lecturer at Brooklyn College. Chloë is currently a visiting artist at Akademie Schloss Solitude.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Wotutu a single mother. I am my daughter's full-time carer and can't get a job due to this. In recent times money has gone down and down and prices of food, electricity has gone higher, I used to be able to make ends meet from doing commissions, but now I've run so low on materials that I can't afford to replace them.

I don't want handouts, I just want to be able to work to earn again.

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • £30 for a laminator (to turn products into keychains and so customers get their commissions without worrying about post damage)
  • Copics markers

I only hope to make enough for a laminator, anything else is a massive plus.

The Impact

Should I be able to reach my own goal of £30 I would be ecstatic. Anything else would be unimaginable, I'd be able to do commissions again and be a provider once more.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word, share this on your facebook!
  • Visit my art page and spread the word (there's still items premade on sale) https://www.facebook.com/WotutusDraws

Thank you everyone in advance for your help!!

story:
White Dwarf Gallery!

UAS is excited to present a new stream of programming! UAS White Dwarf Gallery is a new exhibition space which fosters stronger relationships between artists, arts organizations and the general public.

Located adjacent to UAS Satellite Gallery, White Dwarf Gallery is a new stream of exhibition programming featuring community oriented exhibitions of a boundary pushing nature. 

We envision a free-form gallery space where communities can merge and collaborate, offering ground breaking ideas around community activism to the general public and showcasing the art of marginalized communities. Programming in this gallery follows a specific mandate of highlighting visual art that emphasizes community and collaboration. White Dwarf Gallery is not continually programmed and exhibitions vary in length. 

White Dwarf exhibitions feature cross-programming initiatives with collectives, groups or organizations in the spirit of building community. Solo or duel exhibitions dealing with community, activism or social justice will also be considered. 

At this point in time UAS does not have designated funds to program this space or offer artist fees. Artists or groups exhibiting in the White Dwarf Gallery can work with UAS to pursue alternate means of funding.

We are really excited to already have TWO exhibitions programmed in this space!!

 

Safe Lights:

Exhibition Runs: February 15 – March 9, 2013
Opening Reception: Friday, February 15, 7–11pm

Untitled Art Society is please to present Safe Lights in the White Dwarf Gallery. This exhibition features the work of many Calgary-based photographers who incorporate analogue developing and printing as a crucial aspect of their artistic practice. 


The level of research and technological knowledge required to create these images becomes a critical part of their conceptual framework. The act of printing in a darkroom and the relationships that each artist builds with his or her process is highly physical, time consuming and intimate. 

The utilization of these highly traditional processes as a means of image making re-presents the art historical context of photography in a new and contemporary light. This exhibition can function as an artificial timeline. A wide range of technological eras is being presented, but contentiously marred and subverted with cues of the present day. 

There is a continual binary tension created by these works. Past and present, precious and infinite, tangible and intangible all play into how darkroom photography functions as a contrast to digital photography as a contemporary form of art. 

 

Brandon Dalmer: CRISIUM

Exhibition Runs: March 28 – June 22, 2013
Opening Reception: Friday, May 24, 8–11pm

CRISIUM will be a culmination of the construction of a small fictional spacecraft’s escape pod within the space. This project has a two phases that utilizes the space and installation. First being the actual construction of the craft, will be open to the public to observe as Dalmer constructs the dodecahedron. The second phase will be the exhibition itself, in which viewers are invited to peer inside (but never enter) the elaborate escape pod created by the artist.

Dalmer’s work using comic narrative to present symbolism and archetypes in a more accessible nature. This exhibition will also become a hub for communities to engage the educational elements of Dalmer’s work.

Throughout the process of installation viewers will be invited to enter, and interact with the artist as he creates his work and be exposed to the subtleties of the working process. Showcasing art in progress lends itself easily to advocacy for the arts. Viewers gain the opportunity to become far more engaged as they recognize and respect the commitment, skill, and knowledge involved in being an artist. 

 

Funding the Gallery

At this point in time, UAS does not have dedicated funds to program this gallery separately. Here’s where your contribution will go towards:

  •  Artist fees for Brandon Dalmer (he’s flying in from Toronto to complete this project!!)
  • Artist fees for the artists of Safe Lights
  • Supplies to keep this gallery looking swell (paint, lights, etc)
  • Funds to printing and hospitality for the opening receptions.

 

Having a little extra funds will really help to make this gallery a consitant part of UAS’s programming! Right now our priority is funding the two current projects, but anything beyond the cost of gallery supplies and artist fees used for these two shows will go towards making this gallery a sustainable part of UAS and funding future exhibitions in the white dwarf gallery!!

 

About Untitled Art Society

Situated in the heart of downtown Calgary, UAS supports the education and professional development of early emerging artists through offering subsidized studio space, a black and white darkroom and contemporary arts workshops. UAS exhibitions showcases early emerging artists as an important aspect of critical engagement in provincial contemporary art. 

Vision:
UAS envisions a space where members from various corners of the arts community can gather, exhibit work, produce work, increase artistic knowledge through workshops, and access dialogue and discourse through access to others in the community, in a casual and supportive atmosphere.  UAS is interested in supporting parallel activities such as curatorial practices, art review and critical writing, performance, and off-site art projects.  UAS is an open and inclusive society that is not discriminatory towards any artistic practice, but is simply focused on creating an environment that encourages growth and excellence in art.

Mission:
UAS showcases and provides production facilities to professionals, and occasionally students in the emerging stage of their artistic development for the purpose that their work be considered and recognized by the arts community and the general public. 

Mandate:
UAS is a non-profit, artist-run organization that provides infrastructure and peer-juried exhibition space to Calgary's pre-emerging artists and showcases visual arts and artists from diverse cultures and communities within the city.  UAS functions as a community for artists just finishing their arts education and acts as a meeting place for artists, arts administrators and the public.

 

Thank you!!

Thank you for your support in this exciting new project for UAS! You can help us out just by spreading the word, too. Please share this with your friends and family, stick it on your facebook page, anything you like to help get these going!

 

*Photo courtesy of Brandon Dalmer (from CRISIUM)

story:
The Magazine
InPrint is a creative magazine that can provide a reward, recognition, satisfaction, influence, and a fresh new look into the creative life of an artist, young designers, creative professionals and creative practitioners. We believe InPrint Magazine For Tablets is a new journey outlining a picture of creativity into the future. A new face where we can see and hear something new from the creative environment around the world in a creative publication that will be the inspiration for the rest of your lives!

Product Description

InPrint magazine informs and enlightens the graphic design,illustration and arts professions with in-depth reporting and critical commentary on the emergent issues, trends, and ideas affecting global visual communications.InPrint analyzes the influence and effectiveness of the designer in the worlds of commerce, culture,
and society and presents its observations within a rich and dynamic visual environment.The magazine's goal is to feature artists, whether they work
for a firm, an in-house department, for themselves or run successful, creative, profitable studios.InPrint Magazine strives to serve the business and the creative needs of graphic-design professionals and professionals who are influencing contemporary arts.

Our Video Classes

You set the pace with online learning. Learn what you want, when you want, and practice with the instructor's files while you watch and listen. Our teachers are effective, passionate educators, who are also respected authorities in graphic design, illustration, creative, and media fields. They're here to share their expertise in dozens of topics with you, with courses organized into subject areas.

The Impact

We show contemporary visual arts to a wide variety of audience and that attracts readers from USA, Europe, UK, Spain, France, Germany, Italy, Australia and the rest from all over the world!

InPrint Magazine is read by hundreds of thousands of people and has millions of visits each month! We're present in over 180 countries and continue to grow! you can read our latest issue here http://www.inprint-mag.com/read.html


Budget For InPrint Magazine

How will the money be used?

We want to take InPrint Magazine to a new level of e-magazines where readers will interact with it through their tablets , PC's or touch screen computers. They will be able to watch video interviews, buy art, buy the latest issue, save them on their newsstand, create profiles, appreciate arts, learn with interactive classes,  collect arts an experience a whole new level of interactions with the e-magazine app and website.   

  • The money raised will go towards a application, members sign in page , and administrative cost to run the campaign. The goal of the campaign is $6.000
  • application + apple store and android stores set up - $2500 with tax
  •   second phase of the website - $3000
  • Promotions, Design, Postage, Help to distribute perks - $500

story:
IF the USA are the greatest country in the world... well then I want to appeal to you to help me the underdog. My name is Lucritia Rouse, Yankton Sioux and I´m the descendant of a once proud and mighty people.

I have been the victim of genocide against my family by the State of South Dakota and I need your help!

Help me to fund my campaign to find a civil rights attorney to represent me and my sisters, brothers and cousins!

IMAGINE YOU  ARE arrested on lies like a witch in the dark ages. Nothing you say or do makes any difference to the Verdict... GUILTY

Imagine your children being abducted,starved,tortured& interrogated against you. Imagine prison for 33 years INNOCENT. 

Help me to fund my campaign to free my innocent beloved uncles! I want to travel the United States, Talk to the Media, Press, Senators, Governors, Politicians, Celebrities, Corporate leaders and Officials. I need money to fund my trip and my food. I´m from the Yankton Sioux Reservation in Marty South Dakota. We are poor. I humbly ask you for your help to bring justice to my family. Wopida tanka. (thank you kindly)

Mitakuye Oyasin-we are all related

What happened 20 years ago?

In 1994 the State of South Dakota in cooperation with the FBI and corrupt YS Tribal Officials and chairman removed 11 children from their home on the Yankton Sioux Reservation without a removal order or affidavit. The removal itself was at gun point and illegal.

If this was a play these would be the different stages of plot development…

1. First scene squad cars surround the house and screaming kids are taken

2. Children held at bia office till late at night asking over and over why they have been taken and they can't to go home


3. Foster mothers Donna and Jean cutting the crying childrens hair


4. Interviews with FBI Wim van Roe and Dan Hudspeth (who impersonates FBI Agent), children crying and asking to go to the toilet and asking for food, the fbi denies this and keeps pointing at penises and dolls!!


5. Foster mother Donna Jordan and Jean Brock telling the girls its ok to lie, just lie and you will come home to your family and your uncles and dads will be home too, just lie and we feed you


6. Scene with the alcohol baths, childs face pushed in the soup bowl, another baby kicked down the stairs. locks on the fridge doors, Doog food for the native kids


7. Children searching for food in the barn and stealing the food from the dogs and other animals in desperation


8. Medical exams, doctors raping the girls with colposcopy examination, inserting a metal camera into anus and vagina BUT take no pictures of their disgusting 'EXAMINATION'


9. Court room, children waving at uncles in the dock, guardian ad litem eva cheney ushering them away, throws coat over Jessica to stop her calling out to her uncles in the dock for help


10. Testimony in a secret room via video camera, prosecutor asking the question, guardian ad litem commanding to each child the 'RIGHT' answer ,eva cheney says: "If we convict these guys we go party tonight!!"


11. Verdict is read, grandmother Rosemary Rouse faints, all the mothers faint, screaming and crying


12.Appeal by lucritia rouse for help and for a voice


13. 4 men remain in prison after 20 years with no evidence whatsoever just lies and words by fbi and  social workers, third party statements

The State of South Dakota is holding 4 innocent Native American men in prison without any credible evidence. Requests to judge Lawrence Piersol, 8th Circuit South Dakota to release the 'evidence' have been denied, even to the incarcerated men!

If the state of South Dakota and judge Piersol continue to withold the federal evidence one can challenge EVERYTHING. There is no adjucation, no probable cause and HENCE no reason to hold these innocent men in prison.

Their names are Jesse Rouse, Desmond Rouse, Garfield Feather and Russell Hubbeling. The have now been incarcerated for 20 years.

I ask you WHY?

WHY is my family´s plight ignored? WHY is such a case of blatant injustice ignored? Quote Lucritia Rouse

OPEN LETTER

Mr. Thomas E. Perez, Assistant Attorney General, Civil Rights Division

Mr. Brendon Johnson, US Attorney SD

Mr. Dennis Daugaard, Governor SD, former head of Children’s Home Society 1990

Mr. James Anaya, United Nations Special Rapporteur

Ladies and Gentlemen, we are Lucritia Rouse, Jessica Rouse, Fury Rouse, Trista Rouse and Rosemary Rouse. 

We are victims of the SD foster service. A lot of so called ‘professional’ people build a great career on our families’ misery. For 18 years we have been labeled as sexually abused children when we were never abused. In reality the only people that abused us are the state’s foster parents and law enforcement officials; our so called 'guardian ad litem' who told the prosecutor she was going to party if “we get these guys convicted”. This woman appointed by the court to act in our ‘best interests’ was talking about our innocent uncles. BUT IN THIS DAY AND AGE and IN THE GREATEST COUNTRY IN THE WORLD you can only have justice if you can pay for it? WHY? Why does it cost thousands of $$$$ Dollars for justice to be served when the truth is staring into your face? WHY? As small children we were kept behind electric fences to keep us from escaping the FOSTER ‘CONCENTRATION CAMP’, to make sure we ‘performed’ at trial as ‘instructed’ by government officials!!! It has been 18 years and we have been crying to death ears that NO crime was ever committed against us other then the civil rights violations against us, our families and our innocent uncles. Where are the people with COURAGE who want to stand up for what is right, for the constitution and the truth? FIVE young women, victims of the government and foster care system ask you for help- but who will have the courage to help us? Why is everybody looking the other way? We would like to meet you and talk to you, we will meet and talk and tell the truth, the truth needs to be known of what has happened to us, our families. We have disgusting and sick stories to tell of how the system that should protect children used and abused us.

WE WANT JUSTICE FROM THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA!

Judges can be guilty of failure to prevent a conspiracy in violation of 42 USCA 1986. See also 18 USC 1986

The Hyde Amendment, 18 U.S.C. #3006 (A) and the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA), 28 U.S.C. #2412. These might also apply to a person’s case. A defendant who prevails in a criminal case is entitled to a reasonable attorney's fee and other litigation expenses, where the United States is vexatious, frivolous, or in bad faith. Of course most people are never going to reach the point where they can file for attorney fees and other litigation fees because Judges are going to do everything in their power to see that a person’s conviction is never overturned.






In 1994 the State of South Dakota in cooperation with the FBI and corrupt tribal officials removed 11 children from their home on the Yankton Sioux Reservation without a removal order or affidavit. The removal itself was at gun point and illegal.

If this was a play these would be the different stages of plot development…

1.  first scene squad cars surround the house and screaming kids are taken 

2. children held at bia office till late at night asking over and over why they have been taken and they can't to go home


3. foster mother cutting the crying childrens hair


4. interviews with fbi and dan hudspeth, children crying and asking to go to the toilet and asking for food, the fbi denies this and keeps pointing at penises and dolls


5. foster mother donna jordan and jean brock telling the girls its ok to lie, just lie and you will come home to your family and your uncles will be there


6. scene with the alcohol baths, childs face pushed in the soup bowl, another baby kicked down the stairs. lock on the fridge


7. children searching for food in the barn and taking the food from the dogs 


8. medical exams, doctors raping the girls with colposcopy examination, inserting and poking the vagina and anus several times, BUT take no pictures


9. Court room, children waving at uncles in the dock, guardian ad litem eva cheney ushering them away


10. testimony in a secret room via video camera, prosecutor asking the question, guardian ad litem telling the child the answer ,eva cheney says: if we convict these guys we go party tonight!!
11. verdict is read, grandmother rosemarfaints, all the mothers faint, screaming and crying


12. appeal by lucritia rouse for help and for a voice


13. 4 men remain in prison after 20 years with no evidence whatsoever just lies and words by fbi and  social workers, third party statements

The State of South Dakota is holding 4 innocent Native American men in prison without any credible evidence. Requests to judge Lawrence Piersol, 8th Circuit South Dakota to release the 'evidence' have been denied, even to the incarcerated men!

If the state of South Dakota and judge Piersol continue to withold the federal evidence one can challenge EVERYTHING. There is no adjucation, no probable cause and HENCE no reason to hold these innocent men in prison.

Their names are Jesse Rouse, Desmond Rouse, Garfield Feather and Russell Hubbeling. The have now been incarcerated for 20 years.

I ask you WHY?

WHY is my family´s plight ignored? WHY is such a case of blatant injustice ignored? Quote Lucritia Rouse

Why does Judge Piersol not want to share his evidence on How guilty these 4 men are?

Because He has no evidence other then Evidence of prosecutorial and judical misconduct, racism, corruption and greed. There is PLENTY of evidence for that!!

Lucritia Rouse, the spokesperson for the alleged victims and herself a victim of Judge Piersol and his prosecutors Tapken and Schreier would like to ask all her abusers to take a lie detector test and let her ask the questions.

What exactly do these people think they do know about US, the children that WE do not know? What does Judge Piersol know that we do not know?

What did we do to deserve to be treated worse then animals are treated by the white people of South Dakota?

Why did you starve me?

Why did you call me a 'dirty indian'?

Why did you cut my long beautiful hair? There was no need, We had no lice, We caught lice at the foster home...

Why did you not get me medial attention? If my uncles raped and sodomised me and i was so ripped and torn? Why did you not bring me to a hospital straight away?

But instead you gave me alcohol baths? Why did I have to sit in burning alcohol up to my neck?

Why did you tell me to lie if I want to go home to my mum? Why did you say it is ok to lie?

Why did Judge Piersol, Prosecutors Tapken and Schreier, Holmes and guardian ad litem Cheney STOP us from hugging and kissing our uncles and telling them that we love them and that they love us?

Why did I have to have a metal instrument inserted into my vagina and my anus hurting me by two so-called doctors.

Those doctors hurt and abused me and injured me with their so-called examination?

Why is it ok for these doctors Kaplan and Ferrel to rape me?

Why can Nobody interview our uncles in prison? Whs is this a safety risk and forbidden to the press? Why is the press denied access to the TRUTH about what really happened to all of us?

If my uncles are so guilty why is Judge Piersol hiding the evidence for a Civil Rights Lawsuit? Why is the State of South Dakota controlling the Truth and the Press?

We have a Civil Rights Lawsuit using a SUCCESSFUL case in the United States Court of Federal Claims! 

http://www.narf.org/nill/bulletins/dct/documents/elk.pdf
AND we have a multi-million $  DAMAGE CLAIM under 42-USC 1983 for Genocide against 4 families and unlawful incarceration of 4 innocent men.

BUT who wants to write history and bring this out in the Open?

The Rouse case was a very well-known ICWA case. The case is known for establishing the Existing Indian Family Doctrine. Under the Doctrine, ICWA was not applicable to Indian families if the parent(s) had no cultural connection to their tribe. In other words, if enrolled parent(s) never returned to their reservation, there was no cultural connection and, therefore, ICWA didn't apply. The Existing Indian Family Doctrine was used in several cases and several states adopted it in regard to out of home placement.
25 USC § 1911 - Indian tribe jurisdiction over Indian child custody proceedings | LII / Legal Informwww.law.cornell.edu

The Rouse case is the tip of an iceberg. AND it is the ONLY case that combines within all the motives and interactions that make South Dakota the most racist state in the union. There simply is no other case like the Rouse case.

Everybody involved has made a big career out of the misery of children, mothers and loving families. These people need to be DRAGGED into the light for their disgusting, repellent  and abhorent actions in the name of justice.

please watch this video to learn about the Good, the Bad and the Ugly Players in this SICK charade.

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=278933745577503

The State of South Dakota hands out medals to the killers of innocent women and children to this day and age.

Trista Rouse  http://youtu.be/lEe-Y__uSiU

Lucritia Rouse http://youtu.be/4Z0_GauRN2I

Bill Decker http://youtu.be/X3eeKUVSRvA

If the USA are the greatest country in the world then I want to appeal to you to help me, to help us and give us a voice.

Free us, give us Freedom and Justice.

WITHOUT YOU WE WILL HAVE NO HELP AND NO JUSTICE AND ALL THESE CRIMINALS WHO HURT MY FAMILY WILL GET AWAY WITH THEIR CRIMES AND WILL CONTINUE THE GENOCIDE AGAINST OTHER FAMILIES AND CHILDREN:

SAVE THE CHILDREN OF FUTURE GENERATIONS SO WHAT HAPPENED TO US CAN NEVER HAPPEN AGAIN.

Be the voice of the children. Be the voice of the Innocent. Aho

http://youtu.be/X3eeKUVSRvA
If the USA are the
greatest country in the world then I want to appeal to you to help me, to help
us and give us a voice.
Free us, give us
Freedom and Justice.
WITHOUT YOU WE
WILL HAVE NO HELP AND NO JUSTICE AND ALL THESE CRIMINALS WHO HURT MY FAMILY
WILL GET AWAY WITH THEIR CRIMES AND WILL CONTINUE THE GENOCIDE AGAINST OTHER
FAMILIES AND CHILDREN:
SAVE THE CHILDREN
OF FUTURE GENERATIONS SO WHAT HAPPENED TO US CAN NEVER HAPPEN AGAIN.
Be the voice of
the children. Be the voice of the Innocent. Aho

story:
Just over two weeks left...!

My name is Kate Wood, and I am an artist living on Gabriola Island. Currently I work in a cute little 8 by 12 studio space where I focus on my silver jewellery and clay work.

The reason I am here on Indie Go-go is to raise some money to purchase the supplies I need to carry my plans forward. All my ideas are at a standstill until I have funds to invest in the tools and supplies needed.  What do I need exactly?

My own kiln,(which I have been able to buy second-hand already from this campaign) a shwack of silver, beads, a couple of tools, and maybe hopefully, some screen-printing supplies. I can't get a traditional bank loan so...

I am asking for a little help from those who can, maybe YOU,  and in return you get some handmade  love in return, and also help me on the way to getting ahead. $10 or $25 from everyone I know would sure add up quickly!

 
My Plans are:
    •    to continue to sell at craft fairs off island, and on island
    •    to build my online sales
    •    to pursue more wholesale accounts with stores and galleries
   and-  To continue to find ways to contribute to thie local arts community. (I just got a contract as coordinator for the Isle of the Arts Festival here, and it has been really rewarding)

You can check out more on my work at: katewood.ca,  my etsy shop, or find me at Kate Wood Art and Jewellery page on Facebook.

Thanks for you time,

 Kate

story:
BugMe Art Summary....

My name is Amy Roepnack. I am a mom of two kids and I have been an art teacher for 10 years. Due to recent budget cuts in education, I lost my teaching job. I feel that art is a necessary part of our children's schooling and would like build an art company that will help support the Arts for our children.

I have developed BugMe Art to incorporate kid's names into the artwork. Each name bug is personalized for your little bug. In addition, I created a special art bug to support the Arts. Under the art bug it says  "Catch the Art Bug".

What BugMe Art Needs....

* Funds for a computer & technology to create art bugs
* Funds for printing personalized art, such as, magnets, mugs, t-shirts, and prints
* Funds to advertise BugMe Art
* Funds to help support the Arts in schools

If You Can't Donate....

* Please try to get the word out and make some noise about BugMe Art.

* Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
BRONYEXPO 2014!

The brony community has grown larger and larger in all parts of the world,
and we want to celebrate this by hosting Alberta’s own brony convention, BronyExpo! Come meet other bronies from all over Alberta (and perhaps further) and partake in a weekend of fun and games!

The convention will feature art, music and other creations of the fandom, lots
of games and activities as well as special guests such as:

Andrea Libman (Pinkie Pie & Fluttershy)

 

Michael Daingerfield (Braeburn)

More guests will be anouced as soon as the contracts get handed in!

Edmonton's BronyExpo is hosted by the FANTASYLAND HOTEL at West Edmonton Mall, which is a 4 star Hotel that has rooms fit for an Alicorn!

But we need your help to do it.

Due to the large costs involved in creating a convention of this size, we
need to work together to make it a reality. That’s why we decided to start this
crowd funding campaign. If we meet our goal we can be sure to be able to
deliver a great, high-quality con experience.

BronyExpo is entirely driven by volunteer work only. So none of us are making
money!

Book your tickets early - Save money!

By getting your convention ticket at the same time as you support us through
this campaign! If you choose to donate $50 or more and select the perk will be guaranteed entrance to the convention, as well as a poster for free!

Two days of fun and friendship!

BronyExpo will be two days packed with activities suiting all tastes!
Whether you want to watch panels with interesting bronies, play games with new
and old friends, learn or improve creating art and music at workshops with
skilled creators, shop around for custom pony merch, come see the voice Actors
from the show and get there autograph or just meet people, there will always be
something fun to do no matter your preferences!

Start off your convention summer with us and make memories for life!

 

BronyExpo Supporter Prizes

This poster of Summersweet, Crayon, and Lilac is only available during our IndieGoGo campaign!

You can get this print with any contribution of $20 or more!

 

"Bad Idea, bad idea!" -Summer

For our 20% Cooler Sponsors here are some samples from SpaceVoyager so
you can see just how awesome your custom plushy can look!

 

 

 

And here are some samples from Scarlet Hooves on what your
custom painted mug could look like!

story:
Meet Friday Knights

  Friday Knights is a collective of some of the most eccentric and creative emerging artists from Detroit. Our artists have collaborated with several notable organizations in Metro-Detroit including The Heidelberg Project, Detroit Design Festival, and The Detroit Institute of Arts. Now, we're aiming for new heights and developing more innovative ways to share our art outside of our city limits.

  This campaign is to fund our Visions tour. Inspired by that desire to bring our art and creativity to new places, we decided to put paint to pavement. If musicians can tour, why can’t we? Visions is a means to bring our passions & perspectives from Detroit to different cities, both around the country and around the globe.  The Visions tour will not only show us new horizons and add to our creative ideas, but, hopefully, it will enlighten others to our views on this world we all share, through our ability to create. Our goal is to showcase our artwork in seven to ten different cities in one year.

By making a contribution, you can help us move closer to our dreams. Beyond taking our art beyond borders, the Visions tour will allow us to grow as working artists. Visions has the potential to prove that anything is possible when we all band together to help one another. It is our hope that Visions will encourage the people around us to grow as well.

The Exchange...

The funding for this campaign is for the production and logistics of the entire tour, which will span one year for three artist: (Official dates of shows will be updated)

All funds will go to:

- Venues/Galleries (Galleries usually ask if the artist or artists are partnering

together and far as the entry fee, or if the artist (or artists) will rent for a

certain amount of time.) Which cost approximately $200 to $1000 for either a week or month.

-Traveling expenses (Plane, bus, train tickets, etc.)

·  Plane tickets = $697 - $1450.50

·  Rental Car = $150 - $301 / Gas = $150 - $327

-Shipping the Artwork = $1,340 - $2,249 for 20 to 30 pieces along with insurance.

-Hotel Expenses – cost between $400 and $600 for 3-4 days.

-Art Materials

·  Gallery Wrapped Canvases = $35 - $90 for each canvas

·  Paint = $5.88 - $37.88 for each tube or bottle of Acrylic / Oil Paint

·  Bubble Wrap = $19.97 for 125ft of bubble wrap for shipping

·  Paint Brushes = $2.47 – $20.00  

Any contribution, large or small, is appreciated! Each giving level includes unique perks, from stickers, pins, and apparel to a one of a kind piece of artwork or a customized mural.

  If we do not reach our goal to fund the entire Visions Tour, all of the funds raised will still go towards making our dream a reality. Whether we make $50 or $1000, we will find a way to go on tour. We will do everything we can to showcase our work and bring something unique to different cities around the world with the support from people who believe in us and our dreams.

Supporting Our Dreams & Goals

  Have you ever had a dream or goal that you couldn't reach alone and needed a little help along the way? For us, this is one of those dreams. Where we come from, the Visions tour is an impossible goal in the minds many, but we want to show everyone that you can do anything you truly set your mind to, regardless of systems in place that are working against you. We hope today’s youth will be able to look at this as a mark, that art is still alive and thriving.

We plan to show contributors and the world how far we can take this project and how far we advance even after it is finished. In the end, we hope the artwork we introduce to the world will leave some type of impact on people; art that ignites a feeling like no other.

The Bumpy Road

Creating this tour is a huge challenge. There are many pot-holes on this road we're on and we need the best vehicle to get through it all.

Our main focus is confirming each stop on the Visions tour, but then comes the worry of transporting the artwork and ourselves between stops, having a place to stay, and creating unique pieces of artwork for each unique city (7-10 locations in just one year).

To solve these issues, we work as a team. No artist will face these challenges alone, we will face them as a collective and to the best of our ability, no matter what happens along the way. We’re currently in the process of booking galleries and venues for the tour, to give ourselves time for possible cancellations. We're also working on multiple pieces for the shows in order to have them set for each location. Finally, we’re busy mapping the most efficient way to travel between locations (regardless of mode), and the most sensible places to stay for each stop on the tour.

Anything Helps

  If you cannot contribute to this campaign but would still like to support, there are many ways you can help us pursue our dream.

  Just sharing this campaign through social sites and emails is a huge help. Spreading the word, not only about this campaign but who we are, and what we are trying to achieve will help create an impact beyond our imaginations. You can look for progress from looking up the hashtag #KnightLife. Also if you would like the Friday Knight$ to come to your city and you can connect us to a gallery or venue, email TGIFKS@gmail.com.

When this is all said and done, we, as artists, are nothing without supporters. We appreciate anything, and everything, that you can do to help us reach our goals.

story:
IT IS HERE!

Please enjoy Episode 16 of The Weird Girls Project - #EmbraceYourself


_______________________________________________________________________

#### WOW! Well guys THANK YOU! We are over our original funding goal! I want to update you with stretch goals further down the page to see why your contribution still counts! ####


About this:

The Weird Girls Project is an ongoing art film series created and produced by concept artist Kitty Von-Sometime which is created to empower the women who take part.

Fed up of the media marketing of what a woman's figure should look like and the effect it had on women imposing boundaries to themselves, Kitty started making these pieces, using the 'music video' format to put exposure on the variety of shapes and sizes that make us who we are. 

Volunteer participants take part on a set date and are unaware of any part of the plan until they turn up. This includes the concept, location and costumes. For three months Kitty and the crew plan the piece in secret, and it culminates in a day’s shooting which becomes a film.

The main element of the project is ‘release to the unknown’ and apart from the film the Project focuses on the event itself and how the women react, improvise and morph within costume, learning about their power of self combined with the strength of coming together as a group. 

The Project uses voluntary individuals rather than engaging professional performers or models and part of the ethos is to develop increased self-confidence, especially focusing on body issues and a release of inhibitions. The women are varying in ages, backgrounds and experience, and do not necessarily know each other before the day.

There have been multiple Episodes in Iceland as well as successful financing abroad in Europe and as far away as China. However, without this appeal, the Project will continue to grow abroad without keeping its roots in Iceland, where it was born and developed.


What We Need & What You Get

The money we are appealing for goes on:

  • the hiring of film equipment 
  • costume materials
  • location rental

In return you can scoop up some of our fantastic perks and feel involved in the production of an art piece which is more than just pretty.

For the women in Iceland who have appealed to take part in the Project, the waiting has been 2 years long, you can help bring the series to life again. This appeal is for the cost of the location, costume and equipment only. All crew members including Kitty are producing this voluntarily. The appeal is simply to fund the materials needed for work itself.

The amount of money in the target would allow around 18 women to take part.  There are many more waiting to be included and any financing above this figure would help allow for more women to take part in the piece. 

If the fundraising gathers momentum far beyond its total, we can invest in better equipment and even an exhibition of prints from the piece. 

New Stretch Goals:

  • As we have gone over our total we have added 2 more women and can afford to feed the volunteer crew for the day!
  • If we reach 150% we can invest in higher grade equipment to produce a piece at a standard which will definitely get the video and message on further mainstream platforms
  • If we reach 200% we can host an exhibition of images from the piece.
  • Anything beyond that will go towards the next Episode of The Weird Girls Project - help secure the future!

##### Dollar Drive! #####

We are pushing the $1 drive with this fundraiser. We understand that not everyone has money lying around. But if you can spare just $1 it makes so MUCH MORE difference to our campaign than simply liking or sharing it. 
Liking, sharing, tweeting are great for awareness but mostly leads to more liking, sharing and tweeting. Adding $1 pushes our campaign towards its goal and raises activity on our campaign.


The Impact

Your support of this Project enables its existence to continue. In its history it has pushed individuals who take part to feel better about themselves and beyond that, has encouraged women to welcome who they are. The more successful projects like this are, the more the message of being happy in your own skin gets across. 

In total across the world, 23 pieces have been made in this series, each one individual in its own right. All have been executed successfully. You can be certain that your donation will be secure - supporting a finished film.


Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute financially doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Click on Share!
  • Add us on Facebook and Twitter and spread the love for the Project itself!

facebook.com/theweirdgirlsproject

https://twitter.com/TheWGProject
