story:
How does one study a culture? 

My documentary film, “Mātauranga,” offers a unique way to answer this question by engaging with the Māori based theory of Kaupapa Māori (http://www.rangahau.co.nz/research-idea/27/). This indigenous school of thought serves as an alternative to traditional, dominant practices of ethnographic research. By challenging colonial ideological frameworks, Kaupapa Māori aims to revitalize Māori culture and help reassess traditional research practices in the United States. The film looks at the theory’s impact on Māori society and its potential to encourage new research methodologies in the field of ethnography.

To more effectively convey the principles of Kaupapa Māori, “Mātauranga” includes performance art by Māori artists. Incorporating performances in the film address the significance of using fiction as a platform for ethnography and to ultimately critique early twentieth century ethnographic films of indigenous men and women.

https://www.youtube.com/watchv=vDSuF7qlkhg&list=UUjsBKV1SNdfZqm6RUneAFuw   (Ryan's 2014 documentary short that discusses the effects of ethnographic depictions of Native Americans in the media today)

While Kaupapa Māori is directed at improving the welfare of the Māori nation, the film encourages this unconventional study as an opportunity for people to embrace culturally different styles of learning across the arts and sciences.

----------

Even though funds are initially being raised for camera equipment, this campaign is ultimately a fundraiser for the Native American based theater company, Native Voices (Los Angeles). All equipment earned through this campaign will be sold back and donated to the theater company. All earnings past the goal will go directly to Native Voices.      

                         http://theautry.org/whats-here/about-native-voices      

----------

More info about the Fulbright U.S. Student Program:

http://us.fulbrightonline.org/

-----------

More press about the project:

https://www.oxy.edu/news/last-minute-success-story

http://occidentalweekly.com/ae/2014/09/23/metzler-combines-art-social-justice-post-grad/

http://www.metzlerfilms.weebly.com

-----------

If you have any questions feel free to contact the director:

rywmetzler@gmail.com
story_txt:
How does one study a culture? 
My documentary film, “Mātauranga,” offers a unique way to answer
this question by engaging with the Māori based theory of Kaupapa Māori (http://www.rangahau.co.nz/research-idea/27/). This indigenous school of thought serves as an alternative
to traditional, dominant practices of ethnographic research. By challenging
colonial ideological frameworks, Kaupapa Māori aims to revitalize Māori culture and help reassess traditional research
practices in the United States. The film looks at the theory’s impact on Māori society and its potential to encourage new research
methodologies in the field of ethnography.
To more effectively convey
the principles of Kaupapa Māori, “Mātauranga”
includes performance art by Māori artists. Incorporating performances in the film
address the significance of using fiction as a platform for ethnography and to
ultimately critique early twentieth century ethnographic films of indigenous
men and women.
https://www.youtube.com/watchv=vDSuF7qlkhg&list=UUjsBKV1SNdfZqm6RUneAFuw   (Ryan's 2014 documentary short that discusses the effects of ethnographic depictions of Native Americans in the media today)
While Kaupapa Māori is directed at improving the welfare of the Māori nation, the film encourages this unconventional
study as an opportunity for people to embrace culturally different styles of
learning across the arts and sciences.
----------
Even though funds are initially being raised for camera equipment, this campaign is ultimately a fundraiser for the Native American based theater company, Native Voices (Los Angeles). All equipment earned through this campaign will be sold back and donated to the theater company. All earnings past the goal will go directly to Native Voices.      
                         http://theautry.org/whats-here/about-native-voices      
----------
More info about the Fulbright U.S. Student Program:
http://us.fulbrightonline.org/
-----------
More press about the project:
https://www.oxy.edu/news/last-minute-success-story
http://occidentalweekly.com/ae/2014/09/23/metzler-combines-art-social-justice-post-grad/
http://www.metzlerfilms.weebly.com
-----------
If you have any questions feel free to contact the director:
rywmetzler@gmail.com

story:
In a Nutshell

MY GIFT TO YOU...

My latest series of black white illustrations have been hugely successful selling as individual prints. My NEW project, highlighting these special Nature Illustrations have been compiled into one 11" x 8.5" inch 2019 Calendar with removable pages for you to frame! That's right! Previously available only on my site for the price of $10 per print, you can NOW GET TWELVE individual black and white prints to frame, plus one ADDITIONAL color print that I added my own style of flair to!

All for you for only $30, shipping included!!!

NOT JUST A CALENDAR...

What makes this calendar so special?! Each month, you can remove the print to keep and FRAME or COLOR EACH PIECE, creating your own beautiful gallery of art to hang and display!! It's like we are working on a project together!!!

What's in it For You? 

To make this campaign a real success, my goal is to raise enough to cover basic printing costs for the calendars and prints. You will receive a card stock weight calendar featuring a FULL COLOR NATURE PRINT on the inside cover, AND TWELVE removable monthly black and white illustrations! While the cover is glossy, the inside pages are matte, which means they are ideal for pencils crayons or markers to color if and when you want!!

YOUR PERKS!!!

By selecting the 'Color the Days Away' perk, you get your very own Coloring Calendar.

With the 'Signed, Sealed, Delivered' perk you get an autographed calendar and an additional 8.5" x 11" print on card stock to color and/or frame.

The 'Mélange à Trois' perk, includes a big, poster sized 11" x 17" print on card stock featuring THREE beautiful nature illustrations not included in the calendar. A Calendar is of course, also part of this perk!

Want to give one as a gift? Look for the 'Doodle me This' perk, That gets you two autographed copies of the Coloring Calendar, and one of a kind hand drawn special doodle on the month of your choice! In the comic book biz, it is called 'signed and remarked'... A totally remarkable perk for sure!

Other amazing perks include 'The Fab Five'!!  Yep, that is FIVE Calendars at a reduced quantity price!

Even more exciting is the 'Nothing Like the Real Thing' perk. This allows you to pick from one of the five original pieces available right now... This if for those of you have absolutely have to have the real thing! This is truly one of a kind as there is only ONE Original illustration per perk! Exclusive and Limited... Awesome, right?! And of course a Coloring Calender!!!

Understandably, creating this body of work, designing the calendar, printing copies, autographing, doodling, and mailing take time and effort to say the least. With the flexible funding goal we set, we have made sure that all of these costs are considered, as well as ensuring you will get your perks! 

Also included in the price for your perk are all associated delivery and shipping costs, including proper packaging to get your product to you intact! Just make sure we have your correct email and mailing address!

And so, I gladly present to you my 'Color by Nature 2019, An Illustrated Coloring Calendar by Rob Sacchetto!! Help my project GROW by funding today!

How your Support Helps

You may know me as the originator of Zombieportraits.com. Since that site launched in 2006, my work has been featured worldwide! All that, is thanks to YOU, my fans!!! I have also been supported by fans who have enabled me to successfully fund my other campaigns. I truly hope that this Illustrated Coloring Calendar is the latest example. 

Over the years, fans of my work have helped me to successfully fund and complete other campaigns based on my artwork, including 'Rob Sacchetto's Cape Fear', a 150 page graphic novel, 'Divas of the Dead', a Zombie Pinup book, and 'Color This! Rob Sacchetto's World of Coloring' book.

Meeting our Challenges

One of the greatest challenges with a project like this is completing the vast array of visual content, ie the art! With the majority of the artwork nearly completed, we are working on the final design now! The printer has already been booked and the presses are ready to run for the end of the campaign. This will ensure that we have the finished product in our hands and available to ship to you in time for the holidays and the new year!

And, as an artist who has, since 2006, successfully shipped thousands of original artworks worldwide, I am more than prepared for the task!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute, but still want to help? Share this link with friends and family by using the Indiegogo share features!

story:
WHAT IS THE BOOK ABOUT?

  • Panther is a magical black cat from another planet who can do anything except grant his own wish to become a dog. In an effort to make friends with a human he admires, Panther takes a mysterious offer from mystical beings willing to help him change - but the offer comes at a price.

WHAT AGE RANGE IS THIS BOOK FOR?

  • Ages 4-8

  • Comparables: if you liked The Gruffalo, The Lorax, Dragons Love Tacos, and/or Lily the Unicorn, you'll love this book.

MEET THE YOUNG AUTHORS

We'll be revealing and featuring new authors from this project every week of the campaign. Stop back by to meet more of the young stars who made this book!

]

Joyelle Evans-Nye | Author

A few things about Joyelle in her own words:

  • My favorite animal is a Puppy.

 

  • My favorite part from this workshop is probably when we got to draw the characters for the book.

 

  • My favorite things to do are play a game called Roblox, Watch TikTok videos, Watch tv, Paint, Draw, and cook.

 

  • My favorite things to eat are Pizza, French Fries, Icecream, homemade meatballs, Burgers, Broccoli with garlic salt, Brussel sprouts with garlic salt, and Popsicles.

Some of Joyelle's drawings while she was helping to make this story:

 

WHAT WE NEED + WHAT YOU GET

This $15K will help us produce books and other items at a healthy enough volume that we can be sustainable and continue to foster young imaginations in the future.

The money raised will be used in the manner below:

80% | Developing + Printing the first edition print of THE SECRET LIFE OF PANTHER

20% | Creating Panther NOTEBOOKS and PLUSHES

THE IMPACT

  • Confidence by these young authors to know their art and work is being supported
  • 65% of book sale profits help provide support and developmental services to youth
  • 35% of book sale profits go toward sponsoring other kids to have the chance to experience this workshop and create a book!

THE SUPPORT TEAM

Jesse Byrd | Workshop Creator & Lead

Jesse is an award-winning children's book author, editor, and publisher whose family has been in the book biz for 31+ years with New York Times Bestsellers to their credit. He created this workshop to give kids the hands-on experience of creating a children's picture book from world-building, character development, inserting drama, sketching scenes, story outlining, color use, writing, and more! His hope is that by learning about and working with the ingredients that go into making stories, kids will be able to have a new, wider, and different lens on literacy, reading, and storytelling as a whole. 

Paige A. Mason | Illustrator

Paige is a professional illustrator and elementary school art teacher based in California.

"I do identify myself as a black artist, a black artist who likes to think outside of the box with my silly illustrations. Storytelling, adolescence, and imagination is what can be found in my work; simple drawings that children gravitate to, but also simple drawings that evoke a sense of nostalgia for adults both old and young." - Paige

Dominique Enriquez | JCAS

Dominique Enriquez, Executive Director at the Junior Center of Art and Science is a visual artist, educator, and cultural worker with experience working with youth and adult learners in a variety of community contexts.  She received her Master’s degree in Education from the University of California, Santa Cruz, her B.A. in Studio Art from San Diego State University, and studied Drawing and Painting at the California College of the Arts.  Additionally, she has over 20 years of cumulative experience in dance including hip hop and ballet.  As an experiential learner, Dominique believes in the intrinsic value of creative exploration in the learning process and loves to explore new ideas through observation, dialogue, and hands-on making.

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

Distribution: Our biggest challenge, as with many direct-to-market books, will be placement in bookstores and libraries. Even with over 50% of book sales taking place via Amazon, we are passionate about having a local presence in small and chain bookstores. We have a growing list of ideal locations and will be updating you here as we add new libraries, bookstores, gift shops, and organizations partner to carry this book!

Being Evergreen: It is critical that we build a true and lasting community to expand the lifespan of this work. Any referrals for storytime readings (virtual now, and later, in-person) plus book purchases for schools, libraries, and organizations will be incredibly helpful!
 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We're more effective together. Every purchase, referral, and mention amongst your network truly matters. If you're unable to help fuel this mission financially, please help us out by sharing the word amongst your social and personal circles!

Sincerely,

Paige, Dominique, Jesse, and the kids!

story:
Who are we?! 

We are Good Store Studio! A trio of independent brands who joined forces to create an umbrella brand bringing you independent goodness. In this dream team is Josie Irvine of Palace Flophouse, Beth Izzard of The DIY Supermarket and Emma White of Duvet Days, with the same ethos and passion for independent work it was the perfect match for us to come together and create Good Store Studio ✨

We wanted to be not just a lifestyle store stocking independent goods, we wanted a space that everyone could enjoy, with an open plan textile studio out the back and goal to host workshops for other local independents, we started our journey in Two's Company Studios. We had hoped to be a permanent fixture in Old Market, but we sadly had to just pop-up due to the building being turned into flats by the landlord in the near future. To say the pop-up went well would be an understatement, we were overwhelmed with the response and support you all gave us and our brainchild.

But now our stars have aligned and we have amazingly been able to find a new store to open by the end of the year, the contracts are in place and it's all systems go! It's in Old Market and has heaps of potential, the only downside is it needs quite a bit of work to get it looking top-notch.

Our vision is to create a lifestyle store/textile studio as we had before in Two's Company but also creative desk spaces that can be rented by local creatives. Not only that but the shop/textile studio will all be easily manoeuvrable for workshops, events and anything that works in our new store! What we're hoping is to create a community hub that offers something for everyone, a place people feel comfortable in, and is part of the Old Market community ✌️

 

And What Do We Want?

We're asking for a flexible goal of £10,000, this will support us in totally transforming the new space to be the best it can be. This will include building work such as:

  • a partition wall to separate the space out for our creative desks so we all have some privacy
  • new flooring (nobody likes office carpet tiles...)
  • plastering, painting and tiling
  • shop fittings to showcase our brilliant stock 
  • large fixtures that are custom built to be able to move when we have workshops/talks/clubs using the space, e.g pattern cutting table, till desk area, central display for stock that doubles as a workshop table and many more nifty contraptions! 
  • a show-stopping new shop front

We'd also love this to help us get Good Store up and running smoothly so we can focus on getting people booked in to use the workshop space, manage our new desk spaces and ensure the lifestyle store is beautifully stocked so ideally, we would use the cash for set up costs such as:

  • PRS licence
  • Contents insurance
  • The first round of bills- gas, electric, water, internet and all that jazz

And obviously, there are all the bits that you don't even think about that crop up so anything earnt in this campaign will be SO much appreciated. We've chosen a flexible funding option so if we don't reach our goal we'll still get all of the donations to use towards our venture.

BUT of course you lovely lot don't just get the amazing feeling of helping a new business find it's feet, we have some AMAZING pledge options for you, from creative lessons to one-off pieces, we've literally got something for everyone.

Why Good Store Studio is Needed...

Bristol has had an insanely sad amount of creative venues closed down over the last few years, we need more affordable spaces for people to feel creative and connected.

The ability to have multiple creative desk spaces is so exciting and gifts itself as a welcoming workspace to see creative things happening to inspire others in their day to day work setup. Working in a sociable setting has been seen to enhance proactive working and boost morale, there's a reason creatives in spaces thrive off each other! Beth was previously the studio manager at Two's Company Studios and has seen this first hand, "The community that surrounds a creative space is something truly special, I thought I worked well at home until I had my own studio and then, funnily enough, I got SO much more work done. You can bounce ideas off each other or just take a break from your desk and have a bit of social time, something a lot of freelancers forget they can do!"

With the three of us coming from creative arts backgrounds, with a heavy dose of event planning and logistical minds mixed in, it was obvious that we wanted the Good Store Studio to serve as a bookable space for anything creative. Whether it's workshops, talks, book clubs, monthly meet up clubs, we want the store to be a safe and inclusive space for people to come and explore their passion. As discussed before Bristol has a severe lack of affordable smaller spaces that are hireable by the hour. We want to change that!  

Our lifestyle store can be a hub for discovering new indie designers and brands. With the urge to shop consciously and support independents becoming the norm, we want to be a go-to store that is affordable and accessible for handmade goods. This is not only for the customer but for the seller too, we want to be able to support new creatives in their endeavours in a way that is fair to their art.

In recent times, we feel that focus has been lost on the hard work that goes into the fashion industry, with fast fashion still prevailing. We also understand that fashion-based environments can be daunting, but we want that to change and be an open space that people enjoy coming too. Working mainly with commissions, Palace Flophouse and Duvet Days show you that they don't need to be overpriced and inaccessible, they can be for everyone. It's so important that clothes fit well and are loved; people are more likely to hold onto them forever and cherish their pieces. You'll also be able to speak to Palace Flophouse and Duvet Days about their creations instore with their workspace entwined into the building, it will break down the divide of not knowing who has made your clothes as they will have been created right in front of you in their textile studio. They will have a face and a personality with perks such as free repairs offered and being able to talk about every aspect of your garment.

Other Ways You Can Help Good Store Studio

We know that some of you won't feel you are able to donate to our fundraiser and that is absolutely fine! There are ways to help us if you can't financially:

  • SHARE, SHARE and SHARE! Help us spread the word without spending a penny.
  • Spread the word, verbally tell ANYONE and EVERYONE what we're up to
  • Our social media handles are @goodstorestudio on Facebook and Instagram so you can find us and tell everyone else...
  • If you know of any way we can get more coverage i.e press then please let us know! 
  • Offer to donate a pledge reward, if you have something people would want to donate for drop us a message! 

We cannot thank you enough already, you are all GREAT! 

Josie, Beth and Emma x

Available Pledges to Enjoy:

  • A HUGE Thanks
  • The DIY Supermarket Bundle
  • An even BIGGER thanks
  • Little Blythe Tote and Pin Badge
  • Wilbur Bear Tote and Pin Badge
  • Signed Magnus by Claire Shorrock
  • A HUGE thanks and Launch Pass
  • A HUGE thanks and GSS pin badge
  • Signed Snow Globe Wishes Book
  • A HUGE Thanks and GSS A5 Print
  • Right Good Kitchen Brownie Box
  • Buff Bar x Mimo Cha Set
  • Meal at Suncraft
  • Nick White- This on That Prints
  • Jackie White Cactus Pot
  • Duvet Days Custom Kids Trousers
  • KJS Studio Silk Emma Pouch
  • Good Store Studio T-shirt
  • Palace Flophouse Leggings
  • Good Store Studio Bundle
  • Good Store Studio Long Sleeve T-shirt
  • Claire Shorrock A3 Dog Print
  • Pink Bombyx Long Kimono
  • Bangs Evo Hair Products Packages
  • West St Kitchen Night for Two
  • Cut Film After Effects Lesson
  • Good Store Studio Gift Cards
  • Blue Bell Lino Cut by Sarah Shephard
  • Untitled Lino Cuts by Sarah Shephard
  • Haus of Hair Restyle
  • Duvet Days Custom Trousers
  • Nick White All Shook Up A3 Print
  • Palace Flophouse DIY Workshop
  • Pretty Wild Wreath Workshop
  • Palace Flophouse Romper Suit
  • Duvet Days Custom Top and Trousers
  • Palace Flophouse 2 Piece Set
  • LSTD VIP Weekend Ticket and Merch
  • Duvet Days Jumper and Trousers
  • Palace Flophouse Jumpsuit
  • Palace Flophouse Dressing Gown
  • Good Store Studio GOLD MEMBER FOR LIFE

Contents insurance
The first round of bills- gas, electric, water, internet and all that jazz

And obviously, there are all the bits that you don't even think about that crop up so anything earnt in this campaign will be SO much appreciated. We've chosen a flexible funding option so if we don't reach our goal we'll still get all of the donations to use towards our venture.
BUT of course you lovely lot don't just get the amazing feeling of helping a new business find it's feet, we have some AMAZING pledge options for you, from creative lessons to one-off pieces, we've literally got something for everyone.

Why Good Store Studio is Needed...
Bristol has had an insanely sad amount of creative venues closed down over the last few years, we need more affordable spaces for people to feel creative and connected.
The ability to have multiple creative desk spaces is so exciting and gifts itself as a welcoming workspace to see creative things happening to inspire others in their day to day work setup. Working in a sociable setting has been seen to enhance proactive working and boost morale, there's a reason creatives in spaces thrive off each other! Beth was previously the studio manager at Two's Company Studios and has seen this first hand, "The community that surrounds a creative space is something truly special, I thought I worked well at home until I had my own studio and then, funnily enough, I got SO much more work done. You can bounce ideas off each other or just take a break from your desk and have a bit of social time, something a lot of freelancers forget they can do!"
With the three of us coming from creative arts backgrounds, with a heavy dose of event planning and logistical minds mixed in, it was obvious that we wanted the Good Store Studio to serve as a bookable space for anything creative. Whether it's workshops, talks, book clubs, monthly meet up clubs, we want the store to be a safe and inclusive space for people to come and explore their passion. As discussed before Bristol has a severe lack of affordable smaller spaces that are hireable by the hour. We want to change that!  
Our lifestyle store can be a hub for discovering new indie designers and brands. With the urge to shop consciously and support independents becoming the norm, we want to be a go-to store that is affordable and accessible for handmade goods. This is not only for the customer but for the seller too, we want to be able to support new creatives in their endeavours in a way that is fair to their art.
In recent times, we feel that focus has been lost on the hard work that goes into the fashion industry, with fast fashion still prevailing. We also understand that fashion-based environments can be daunting, but we want that to change and be an open space that people enjoy coming too. Working mainly with commissions, Palace Flophouse and Duvet Days show you that they don't need to be overpriced and inaccessible, they can be for everyone. It's so important that clothes fit well and are loved; people are more likely to hold onto them forever and cherish their pieces. You'll also be able to speak to Palace Flophouse and Duvet Days about their creations instore with their workspace entwined into the building, it will break down the divide of not knowing who has made your clothes as they will have been created right in front of you in their textile studio. They will have a face and a personality with perks such as free repairs offered and being able to talk about every aspect of your garment.

Other Ways You Can Help Good Store Studio
We know that some of you won't feel you are able to donate to our fundraiser and that is absolutely fine! There are ways to help us if you can't financially:


SHARE, SHARE and SHARE! Help us spread the word without spending a penny.
Spread the word, verbally tell ANYONE and EVERYONE what we're up to
Our social media handles are @goodstorestudio on Facebook and Instagram so you can find us and tell everyone else...
If you know of any way we can get more coverage i.e press then please let us know! 
Offer to donate a pledge reward, if you have something people would want to donate for drop us a message! 

We cannot thank you enough already, you are all GREAT! 
Josie, Beth and Emma xAvailable Pledges to Enjoy:

story:
"The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex."

- 19th Amendment

100 Years of Voting Rights for Women

Maren Conrad, one of California's most inspiring and active muralists, is seeking to inspire citizens to make their voices heard this November! 

To commemorate 100 years of the 19th Amendment since its passage in 1920 we are seeking funds to celebrate the lives of 19 lesser known, but massively impactful suffragettes. These women helped secure women the right to vote through the campaigning for and signing of the 19th Amendment. More often than not these women – already marginalized by their sex and gender – were also seen as lesser due to their race, background, and sexuality and thus have been forgotten by mainstream history books. 

The mural will be located at 19th and K Streets wrapping around the WEAVE, Inc. building in Midtown Sacramento and wrap around the west, north, and east sides.

This mural will not only bring these leaders to the forefront but inspire today's citizens to become active voters and community participants while also reclaiming part of Sacramento for the community.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $20,000 in order to prep the site, purchase supplies, and ensure lighting and graffiti protection as well as provide fair wages for the lead artists and the all-female assistant artist crew. 

A number of unique perks are available from suffrage-themed art prints to one-of-a-kind commissions from Sacramento's favorite muralist. Most exciting are the plaques that will be mounted with the mural, displaying the names of informed and compassionate voters who make this public art piece possible.

About the Mural

The mural's goal is two-fold: inspiration and education.

The mural will inspire all citizens to register to vote and have their voices heard. Voting is one of the great unifiers of our nation — a calling where every individual regardless of party affiliation, gender, race, sexual orientation, religion or any other identity can agree to its importance in shaping our communities, state, and nation. 

By creating a unique selfie-focused destination mural, we hope to encourage community activism, drive voter registration, and a generate place to gather and reflect before heading to the polls. Furthermore, as COVID-19 impacts in-person voting, this interactive mural provides a place for people to declare to the world that they voted. 

The other goal is education. We want to bring the names, stories, and voices of important suffragettes to the forefront. The struggle for the right for women to vote nationwide was one borne by women of various backgrounds, but all sharing one ideal: that women's ideas of a more perfect union are equal to that of men. QR codes next to each portrait will connect viewers through their phones to short biographies of the women to help people learn about these suffragists; essentially, turning the building into a virtual outdoor history museum.

Who are the women?

(When we first announced the project we revealed these seven diverse suffragists, encompassing a range of experiences and backgrounds. For the complete list of all 19, see the Updates section.)

Naomi Anderson: An African American suffragist, civil rights activist, and poet who highlighted the experience of African American women who were still enslaved by their inability to vote.

Mary Church Terrell: An African American suffragist who helped found the National Association of Colored Women in 1986 and served as its first national president. In addition, she was a founding member of the National Association of College Women.

Mabel Ping-Hua Lee: The first woman to receive a PhD. from Columbia University and a well-known figure in the women's suffrage movement. Even after the passage of the 19th, Lee was unable to vote because of the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 until it was repealed years later.

Maria Guadalupe Evangelina de Lopez: A California suffragist and an educator, she campaigned and translated at rallies in Southern California where suffragists distributed tens of thousands of pamphlets in Spanish.

Marie Louise Bottineau Baldwin:  A Métis Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians attorney and Native American rights activist who emphasized the value of traditional Native cultures while asserting her own place in the modern world as an Indian woman.

Laura de Force Gordon: A California lawyer, newspaper publisher, and a prominent suffragette. She was the first woman to run a daily newspaper in the United States and the second female lawyer admitted to practice in California.

Luella Johnston: The first woman elected to the Sacramento City Council and the first woman to be elected to the city council of any major city in the United States.

Why Purple, White, and Gold?

The Suffragist, Vol. 1 No. 4, published on December 6, 1913, describes the symbolism of the colors for the suffragette movement. “Purple is the color of loyalty, constancy to purpose, unswerving steadfastness to a cause. White, the emblem of purity, symbolizes the quality of our purpose; and gold, the color of light and life, is as the torch that guides our purpose, pure and unswerving.”

Sunflowers and roses, popular symbol of the suffrage movement in the U.S., also adorn the mural. 

Interactive Elements

A speech bubble declaring the words, "I VOTE!" will be emblazoned under the images of famous suffragettes, inviting all voters to come and celebrate their right. 

About the Artist

Maren Conrad - Lead Artist

For over a decade, Maren Conrad’s engaging works have embraced a range of humanity’s obsessions from storied mythologies to pop culture icons. Unafraid to broach divisive, feminist ideals while embracing play, her work has been lauded for its colorful, bold and unflinching commentary on the role of women on the global stage — at times even bubbling into international controversy. 

As a female muralist, Maren Conrad is driven to transform dangerous, neglected alleyways into playful, poignant and engaging destinations. By activating once avoided places into share-worthy stages communities can reclaim their spaces, empower their denizens, and narrow the urban-planning gender gap. 

Many of Conrad's murals have become destinations throughout Sacramento including the Wishing Wall, Transcontinental Railroad, Mr. T, and the Koi Mural on the MAARS Building in Midtown. 

Read more at her website: https://www.marenconrad.com

The mural team consists of a number of diverse local artists and professionals, almost entirely women, with members from various racial, ethnic, religious, and LGBTQI+ communities. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? We can still use your help! Be sure to share this campaign on social media and encourage others to chip in!

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Story

My name is Violet Kirk and I am a Texas born artist. Art to me is precious and if I could I would do it 80 hours per week. With that being said the best way to make my dream a reality is to start with the one and only New York Art Expo. Many famous artist received their start attending this event and turning their dream into a reality. The only issue is without you its just that a dream. Below are some videos and photographs of my art as well a little more about me.

Maleficent


About Violet Kirk

Violet Kirk  is  a self-taught artist, sculptor and photographer. Her beginnings are humble as she came from a rough neighborhood in Fort Worth. Despite many obstacles placed before her she never let her passion for what she loved be waivered. She  has competed in state and national photography  art contests placing in the top 3 on multiple occasions even finishing 1st and 3rd during the same event. Violets art has been displayed in the Texas Cowgirl Museum in Fort Worth Texas and has been featured in Niji and The Alchemist Magazines.  You can view further art pieces at www.VioletKirk.com.

Perks: What you get for helping In exchange for helping me fund my campaign I will be offering a wide range of perks from small hand painted mixed media to large portraits. This is your chance to acquire some one of a kind original artwork.

 Stretch Goal: In addition to the perks that are already created I will also create new perks once certain dollar amounts are exceeded. These perks will include everything from autographed prints to even larger mixed media pieces. I will listen to you comments and will create additional perks based on your wants.

What do you plan to do with the Money?

The money donated from you will assist me in purchasing exhibit space. I am including a pricing sheet from the Art Expo website showing the different exhibit space pricing. Anything over my original goal will go toward a larger exhibit space and shipping of additional exhibit pieces. Without you I wont be able to attend and showcase my art so thank you. If things work out the way I hope they do I would like to purchase multiple exhibit space at the expo, as well as have a personal art showing when I get back to Texas with a formal meet and greet for all my backers.

Please follow me on Twitter https://twitter.com/kirk_violet and Facebook https://www.facebook.com/VioletmKirk85.


Thank you all for your support.

story:
10 Days

750+ Artists

400,000 Visitors

Unlimited Possibilities

The 55th Dollar Bank Three Rivers Arts Festival on June 6-15 presents 10 full days of FREE visual and performing arts throughout Point State Park, Gateway Plaza and the Cultural District in the heart of Pittsburgh. Nowhere else in the country rivals the caliber and size of our Festival, featuring such acts this year including Jeff Tweedy of Wilco, Trampled by Turtles, Kaiser Chiefs and Lucinda Williams. Public art sculptures, gallery exhibitions, theater and dance performances abound throughout the Festival’s footprint.


PRICE OF ADMISSION: $0.00!


Your support is vital! Together, we can keep this world-class tradition FREE for everyone.

How is this possible?  The Pittsburgh Cultural Trust, non-profit producer of the event, is supported by a growing community of individuals, foundations, and corporations who believe in the arts and this iconic Pittsburgh celebration. 

Your individual contribution directly supports 10 days of:

  • National and local musical performances on the main and satellite stages around the Festival

  • Public art displays and gallery exhibitions

  • Children’s activities that inspire an appreciation for the arts

  • Experimental theater and dance – never before seen productions

By donating a gift of $50 or more, you help to ensure the future of our Festival.  In addition to the gratification of supporting the Festival, you receive stellar perks that may include:

  • Festival merchandise

  • Free Parking

  • Limited edition memorabilia

  • Name listing in the Festival program book


WHY WE DO IT

Art matters.  We envision our region as a place where impactful, artful experiences contribute directly to the quality of life for everyone and are embraced as essential for the entire community.

HOW WE DO IT

We talk and make art.  We envision the Festival as a safe place for the open exchange of creativity and dialogue, ideas and participation.

WHAT WE DO

We present everything from “fun” to “wow factor.”  We envision a full spectrum of programming that collectively creates vibrancy throughout downtown Pittsburgh, provides respite and fun, and evokes a sense of awe and wonder.


Our History

Founded in 1960 by the Women’s Committee of the Carnegie Museum of Art, Three Rivers Arts Festival has presented, during its vast and varied history, more than 10,000 visual and performing artists and entertained millions of residents and visitors. Such notable and memorable stage performances have included Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Charles, Phillip Glass, Steven Reich, Smokey Robinson, as well as literary legends Allen Ginsberg and Spalding Gray. Contemporary dance artists Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane, Lar Lubovitch, Pucci:Sport and many others have performed.  Recent past concerts have featured Norah Jones, The Avett Brothers, Wilco, Sonic Youth, The Wailers and the Black Keys.  Among the long list of visual artists who have graced the Festival galleries and public exhibition spaces, noted visionaries have included Otto Piene, Louise Nevelson, Keith Haring, and Nam June Paik.

In 2009, Three Rivers Arts Festival faced a new turning point in its history as a production of the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust, further advancing the shared mission of each organization to foster economic development through the arts and to enhance the quality of life in the region.

story:
« Je veux faire entendre la parole des auteurs d’une génération dont la pensée s'est développée en même temps que l'arrivée de l'Internet dans leur quotidien, une génération dont l'écriture est influencée par la logique des moteurs de recherche, la cybernétique et le microformat. » -Alix Dufresne, metteure en scène

Alix Dufresne nous promet avec Nuits frauduleuses un spectacle hors normes qui flirte avec la performance autour des écrits des poètes québécois de la Génération Y. En lien avec tout le monde, mais séparée de lui par un écran, cette génération connait la guerre sans jamais y avoir été confrontée, expérimente les douleurs de l'amour dans le réel et le virtuel et maitrise l'art du GIF, du MEME et de l’ÉMOJI à un niveau virtuose. Quelle est alors la place de la poésie dans cette frénésie? Quelle est la place du verbe gratuit, de la parole-mystère, de la jouissance du mot? Nulle part. À moins que la poésie ne s'ajuste à cette nouvelle réalité?


Quand le numérique s'insère en poésie
Les outils de recherche personnalisés, les algorithmes sensibles à nos préférences et autres cookies sont tous des outils que nous utilisons quotidiennement et auxquels nous avons adapté notre façon de penser afin de pouvoir se renseigner, se divertir, travailler ou communiquer. La question que pose Nuits frauduleuses est la suivante: et si cette nouvelle façon de penser avait changé notre façon d'écrire et de lire la poésie? Est-ce que notre ère numérique a rattrapé le genre? En témoignent les écrits des auteurs de la génération Y,  génération qui a connu l'Avant et l'Après Internet. Une génération de poètes qui prend aujourd'hui parole et qui, consciemment ou inconsciemment, reflète inévitablement dans son écriture cette marque qu'a laissé sur eux la technologie. Il y a Steve Savage, avec Nathalie, qui a construit un roman entier dont les phrases proviennent de ses recherches sur le net débutant par "Nathalie est ...". Il y a Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf avec Cavalcades en Cyclorama, un texte absurde et baroque qui imite la logique des moteurs de recherche et dont l'écriture est basée sur l'association d'idées. Il y a Daphnée B. qui passe son "petit dimanche tranquille à googler ses maladies." Il y a Mathieu Arsenault, Daniel Leblanc-Poirier, Marjolaine Beauchamp, Samuel Mercier, et  tous ceux dont l'écriture tranchante et juste laisse entrevoir une parole qui questionne leur place dans le monde, tout en refusant de se faire avaler par la machine. Mais la technologie, bien qu'elle laisse une empreinte sur leur vie et leur création, ils ne la subissent pas, ils s'en servent. Et le résultat est enthousiasmant. 

Certes, l’ère du numérique comporte son lot de problèmes et de limites. Nous sommes perpétuellement divertis: jamais un silence, jamais un temps mort, jamais une attente qui ne soit comblée par autre chose. Alors, où est la place pour la parole poétique, la lenteur du mot, la saveur d'un vers? Comment intéresser le lecteur à une écriture mystérieuse, lente et complexe? Avec Nuits Frauduleuses, nous pensons qu'il serait inutile de lutter contre le rythme et la logique qu'impose notre époque et qu'il est impératif de s'y plonger pour mieux la comprendre et s'approprier ses enjeux. S'adapter pour mieux pervertir, détourner, réinventer, et régénérer l'empreinte qu'ont sur nous les nouvelles technologies par la parole poétique; voilà ce que nous cherchons à faire.

La pièce en quelques points
Maxime Paré-Fortin, Jérémie Francoeur, Philippe Boutin et Marilyn Perreault diront les mots de Marjolaine Beauchamp, Samuel Mercier, Steve Savage, Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf, Laurie Bédard, Daniel Leblanc-Poirier, Daphnée B., Stéphane Surprenant, Mathieu Arsenault, Benoît Jutras, Maude Veilleux et Alexandre Dostie.

Pour ce faire, nous nous plongerons au coeur de la technologie en faisant monter sur scène l'image numérique afin de la faire cohabiter avec la parole poétique, tout ça, avec l'aide de HUB Studio, un collectif de vidéastes qui se spécialise dans le contenu et l'intégration vidéo aux arts de la scène. Ensemble, nous tenterons de réfléchir aux questions suivantes: Un vers et un GIF peuvent-ils cohabiter? Un Haïku peut-il être populaire sur Twitter? La poésie est-elle un médium intéressant à mettre en live feed? Un karaoké sur scène peut-il redonner aux gens le goût de la poésie lorsqu'ils l'interprètent eux-mêmes? Comment faire entrer la poésie dans notre frénésie digitale quotidienne?

Présentation de l'organisme
J'le dis là  est une jeune compagnie qui s’engage à faire entendre des voix dramaturgiques insoupçonnées en montant des textes francophones. L’exploration physique, spatiale et conceptuelle est au cœur sa démarche, le texte est le point de départ et le moteur de la création. En explorant avec humour des thèmes graves, parfois tabous, J’le dis là, souhaite mettre en lumière les enjeux de notre société et amener les spectateurs à aiguiser leur regard sur le monde. J’le dis là  a été crée en septembre 2011 par ses trois membres actifs, Marc Béland, Fabien Dupuis et Catherine Vallée-Grégoire. C’est en octobre 2012 que la compagnie a présenté sa première création, Isabelle, à la salle Jean-Claude Germain, à la suite de quoi Paule Maher a vendu le spectacle à travers le Québec. En 2014, la compagnie intègre Alix Dufresne, jeune metteure en scène et chorégraphe, et produit son premier spectacle ( Les Paroles ) au théâtre Prospero. Depuis, la compagnie a produit quatre créations d'Alix Dufresne.

http://theatredaujourdhui.qc.ca/nuitsfrauduleuses
story_txt: « Je veux faire entendre la parole des auteurs d’une génération dont la pensée s'est développée en même temps que l'arrivée de l'Internet dans leur quotidien, une génération dont l'écriture est influencée par la logique des moteurs de recherche, la cybernétique et le microformat. » -Alix Dufresne, metteure en scèneAlix Dufresne nous promet avec Nuits frauduleuses un spectacle hors normes qui flirte avec la performance autour des écrits des poètes québécois de la Génération Y. En lien avec tout le monde, mais séparée de lui par un écran, cette génération connait la guerre sans jamais y avoir été confrontée, expérimente les douleurs de l'amour dans le réel et le virtuel et maitrise l'art du GIF, du MEME et de l’ÉMOJI à un niveau virtuose. Quelle est alors la place de la poésie dans cette frénésie? Quelle est la place du verbe gratuit, de la parole-mystère, de la jouissance du mot? Nulle part. À moins que la poésie ne s'ajuste à cette nouvelle réalité?Quand le numérique s'insère en poésieLes outils de recherche personnalisés, les algorithmes sensibles à nos préférences et autres cookies sont tous des outils que nous utilisons quotidiennement et auxquels nous avons adapté notre façon de penser afin de pouvoir se renseigner, se divertir, travailler ou communiquer. La question que pose Nuits frauduleuses est la suivante: et si cette nouvelle façon de penser avait changé notre façon d'écrire et de lire la poésie? Est-ce que notre ère numérique a rattrapé le genre? En témoignent les écrits des auteurs de la génération Y,  génération qui a connu l'Avant et l'Après Internet. Une génération de poètes qui prend aujourd'hui parole et qui, consciemment ou inconsciemment, reflète inévitablement dans son écriture cette marque qu'a laissé sur eux la technologie. Il y a Steve Savage, avec Nathalie, qui a construit un roman entier dont les phrases proviennent de ses recherches sur le net débutant par "Nathalie est ...". Il y a Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf avec Cavalcades en Cyclorama, un texte absurde et baroque qui imite la logique des moteurs de recherche et dont l'écriture est basée sur l'association d'idées. Il y a Daphnée B. qui passe son "petit dimanche tranquille à googler ses maladies." Il y a Mathieu Arsenault, Daniel Leblanc-Poirier, Marjolaine Beauchamp, Samuel Mercier, et  tous ceux dont l'écriture tranchante et juste laisse entrevoir une parole qui questionne leur place dans le monde, tout en refusant de se faire avaler par la machine. Alors, où est la place pour la parole poétique, la lenteur du mot, la saveur d'un vers? Comment intéresser le lecteur à une écriture mystérieuse, lente et complexe? Avec Nuits Frauduleuses, nous pensons qu'il serait inutile de lutter contre le rythme et la logique qu'impose notre époque et qu'il est impératif de s'y plonger pour mieux la comprendre et s'approprier ses enjeux. Phaneuf, Laurie Bédard, Daniel Leblanc-Poirier, Daphnée B., Stéphane Surprenant, Mathieu Arsenault, Benoît Jutras, Maude Veilleux et Alexandre Dostie.Pour ce faire, nous nous plongerons au coeur de la technologie en faisant monter sur scène l'image numérique afin de la faire cohabiter avec la parole poétique, tout ça, avec l'aide de HUB Studio, un collectif de vidéastes qui se spécialise dans le contenu et l'intégration vidéo aux arts de la scène. La poésie est-elle un médium intéressant à mettre en live feed? Un karaoké sur scène peut-il redonner aux gens le goût de la poésie lorsqu'ils l'interprètent eux-mêmes? story:
Hello!

I’m Jessica Pleyel, an artist/activist/educator located in Iowa City. I am humbled and honored to be an artist-in-residence at Feast Arts Center in Tacoma for the month of August! During this residency, I will be organizing a version of the To(get)her project, teaching four community-wide classes, and creating a new project expanding to discussion on gun violence in the United States.

What is To(get)her?

The To(get)her project brings a variety of self-identifying women together to destroy wax assault rifles with domestic tools. These guns act as a metaphor for the violence that happens to many women on a daily basis.

Not only are many of our bodies attacked mentally, physically and sexually, but also the government stakes claim on our bodies. With 138 representatives voting against the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA), and many of those same representatives also voting against stricter gun regulations it is apparent that these politicians do not see it problematic that women's bodies are targets.

The ways in which the women choose to melt the guns vary, as well as the domestic tools they utilize. When the women come together, their connections are empowering, often fierce, sometimes gentle, and always meaningful.

As women, when we are together and our voices are loud -- and in unison, we are strong.

What We Need:

The funding goal to get the To(get)her projects up and running at Feast Arts Center in Tacoma is $3500. This will cover shipping artworks, transportation expenses, and buying and creating new materials for the next To(get)her projects.

Anything surplus funds that exceed the goal will be donated to the Women’s Support Shelter in Tacoma.

If you donate to the To(get)her project, you will receive special perks and gifts from previous and current versions of the project, and be thanked at the exhibition!

The Impact:

The To(get)her project has previously been performed in two iterations. Both versions have successfully brought communites together to discuss the pertinent issues of sexual assault and domestic violence in the United States. 1 in 4 women will be in a domestic violence situation and 1 in 6 will be raped in their lifetimes-- and these are the women who come forward. Many women, myself included, do not come forward to persecute their perpetrator for fear of retaliation, triggering memories, or the understanding that most assailants will never see jail time.

Through these performances, women have found solace in one another and themselves through the catharsis of melting and destroying wax assault rifles.

These women have been able to share as much of their stories as they feel comfortable in a safe and loving space. The To(get)her project is about community and growth, and it is my hope to bring together a community of self-identified women in Tacoma to create a new version and spark discussion within this community.

While at Feast Arts Center, I will also be initiating an open community project, in which we will be melting wax assault rifles with domestic tools as a means of catharsis and criticism of the many mass shootings that have plagued the US in recent history. This collective melting of guns will be turned into a painting that will be hung in the gallery for the duration of the art exhibit.

Finally, I will be teaching four classes while at Feast which include: Mold Making 101, Introduction to Healthy Relationships, Performance Strategies, and Embodied Autobiography. These classes will be open to the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate-- that's okay! Please share this campaign with anyone who may be able. 

Thank YOU for making To(get)her a possibility!

story:
The model is simple: CSArt Ottawa curates a season of Ottawa-based artists; patrons purchase a subscription; the money is shared amongst the artists; the artists make original works for all of the subscribers; we throw a party about it.

Want in? Let’s do this.


Season Announcement

Announcing our 2016-2017 Season Artists:

The PepTides, rocking pop 9-piece band with a funky performance style, October 17-23, 2016

THUNK! Theatre, performance duo working in community connection, November 21-26, 2016

Mark B. Stephenson, painter and maker joining tech with technique, February 12-18, 2017

Susie Osler, nature-inspired ceramic artist with an eye for environment, April 1-7, 2017

Chris Turnbull, experimental poet bringing words to new places, May 22-27, 2017


Go to csartottawa.ca for project details.


What You Get:

Subscribers of the 2016-2017 Season will receive:

  • Five original, limited-edition works of art from the season’s artists delivered throughout the year, including tickets for two to an exclusive concert and a live theatre show, a painting, a piece of ceramic art, and a book of poetry (see season announcement for details);

  • Exclusive event invites for food, drink, and artistic merriment;

  • Insider access to the creative process, meeting the artists and getting in on the creation ground floor;

  • The joy of making cool stuff happen in Ottawa.

PLUS, subscribe now through our Indiegogo for:

  • No HST --save $52!

  • A free CSArt T-Shirt 


Other Perks

Give to our campaign and get art teasers from our season’s artists. Ceramics from Susie, drawings from Mark, songs from the Peptides, QT with THUNK! Theatre, and poetry from Chris will give you a taste of what’s in store for CSArt Ottawa 2016-2017.

Or, sport your Ottawa pride with our sweet new t-shirts, Ottawa (de)tours tickets, or a stylized print of Ottawa from The Most Canada.


What We Need


CSArt Ottawa aims to be a fully self-sustaining initiative, with no need for outside funding once we’ve formed a strong subscriber base. All we need is a little boost to get off the ground. That's why early subscriptions are so important.


1) Subscriptions

Support early, and make CSArt Ottawa a reality. Keep your finger on the pulse of the Ottawa arts scene by letting CSArt Ottawa keep you up to date on who’s moving and shaking in our community. Get 5 original, limited editions art works per year, access to exclusive arts events, and opportunities to meet the artists. If we can get 20 early subscribers by the end of this campaign ($8000), then we can get a move on making our first season as amazing as possible. Every subscription counts.


2) Supply Fund

Our goal is to pay artists for their work: their creative ideas, and the time and sweat it takes to make them happen. So how do we make that possible for the art forms that cost a lot to produce (theatre, music), paying those artists the same as those in art forms that cost less to produce (writing, storytelling)? We created the Supply Fund to answer that question. Our season's artists can access the CSArt Supply Fund to help level the playing field. We aim to have a supply fund starter of $1200 by the end of this campaign. The more we have in our Supply Fund, the more diverse art forms we can support --and as Canada's first multi-disciplinary community-supported art project, that's really important to us.


The Impact

Do you reject the idea that Ottawa is boring? Good. So do we.

There’s a gap separating artists and patrons in Ottawa. Let’s close it, let’s recognize our artists as important contributors to our city, let’s build community, and let’s have a hell of a good time doing it.

CSArt Ottawa will pay artists to create original work, make this work accessible to patrons, and add to the great stuff happening in our city.


Team

Megan Piercey Monafu is an Ottawa-based artist who makes things happen. With a diverse background in writing, directing, facilitating, community development, and start-ups, Megan has the connections and skills to get this off the ground and to shine a spotlight on Ottawa’s arts community.

But she won’t do it alone --the CSArt Advisory Committee is there to help, with skills in marketing, outreach, finance, event planning, web design, and more. With a full leadership team of 6 plus a first season involving 14 of Ottawa’s finest artists, CSArt Ottawa is set to knock yer socks off.


Risks & Challenges

Artists are risky people. It’s true. They set out with a seed of an idea and a little pocket change, and who knows what they’ll end up creating.

Patrons are risky too. Audiences change their minds all the time about whether or not they like an artist, and artists spend a lot of time and energy trying to figure out what will entertain and touch their patrons.

We want to build a relationship of trust and respect between artists and patrons, providing patrons with a way to support artists financially and artists a new way to connect with patrons. Together, we share in the risk of the creation process. But, we also share in whatever awesome stuff comes out of it.


Why are the subscriptions so damn expensive?

It’s a challenge of our initiative: providing enough cash to artists that they can create original work for all of our subscribers, while still being financially accessible to subscribers. The money spent on subscriptions goes to the artists’ labour, the event planning, the supplies, and getting the art to you.

Think of this way: if last year you bought 2-3 pieces of art, 2 tickets to a live concert, and 2 tickets to a theatre performance, you probably spent at least $400 all told. We’re asking you to take the leap of spending that money up front, and then have all these things provided to you throughout the year. That means all your money stays in Ottawa, supporting our local economy, with the added bonus that the art is designed specifically with you in mind.


About Community-Supported Art:

Community-Supported Art is modeled after the Community-Supported Agriculture (or ‘farm share’) model of food distribution, where customers deal directly with farmers, investing funds at the beginning of the growing season. This upfront investment allows the farmers to create a harvest of healthy, organic, and local food, which is delivered to customers on a weekly basis throughout the harvest. Everyone shares in the inherent risk of farming as well as in the bounty of a good harvest, and buyers are more connected to their food, to the natural season, and to the local economy.

The first CSArt project was created by Springboard for the Arts in St. Paul, Minnesota, and has since been replicated across the US as well as in Hamilton/Burlington, ON and Montreal, QC.

CSArt Ottawa aims to take the best from the existing models and create a new, multidisciplinary platform --the first of its kind in Canada. Our subscribers will fund and receive work from artists in the Ottawa region, and Ottawa artists will connect with new audiences. Just as participation in Community-Shared Agriculture provides healthy, local food and a greater understanding of the local farming process, participation in our CSArt season will provide exciting local works and a greater understanding of the process and individual artists.


Sharing is Caring

We get that you can’t give to every cool crowd-funding thing that comes your way, no matter how good the perks. Sharing this campaign on your social media and with your friends is still a huge help to us. Let Ottawa know that a great new thing is coming its way!

Art 4 All People is in transition and transformation.

We hope to substain our studio for current arts and healing programs, services, and new projects. To do that we need your help. 

This fundraiser will support Art 4 All People's ecology, expansion, and transformation. .

The money raised in this campaign will be used for 

  • teaching, accounting, and administrative pay 
  • marketing and promotion to get more clients. 
  • creation of new Transformative Art programs 
  • create a new book on Compassion and Creativity for children 
  • TLC to the studio ~ book shelves for paint, art supplies
  • Ability to offer free art workshops to chronically ill children via the organization Coach Art Kids
  • Education of the public about the empowering arts and healing movement 
  • If we get on our feet, we would love to do another public Arts and Healing interactive and engaging Art exhibition.
It would be incredible if you would donate to Art 4 All People. Click HERE to support the healing power of Art. and please pass it on.We want to thrive as an Arts & Heal org! 


We are casting Indra’s net to the universe and seeing what we can catch.

Our names are Ceylan Hulya and Lisa Rasmussen. We are two women on an Art Empowerment mission. In 2012 we co-founded and created an art organization, Art 4 All People LLC. With the idealism and passion to transform and heal individuals, communities, and the world through  art and its magical processes. Over this past four years it has happened ~we have transformed, served, and empowered people through Arts amazing healing processes. We developed a powerful new Art and Healing modality called YogART. At the heart of all of our healing arts (YogART) programming is a sense of empowering each individual to regain a sense of harmony, reverence, balance and to awaken inner resources for healing and creativity. We curated and created powerful Arts and Healing exhibitions. As well as written a book on creativity and compassion. In our heart and souls, we know that Art 4 All People is our higher calling and truly has the power to shift the paradigm to inclusivity and empowerment. But unfortunately, like many Transformative Art organizations are facing some challenges, as well as opportunities. 

What We Need & What You Get.

This campaign is very important to us so that we can continue to serve, transform, and empower the world through art and its amazing processes. 
In Reciprocity and Higher Service, Lisa and Ceylan

 Your support makes a big difference toward reaching our sustainability goal . If we reach our goal, we'll be able to give the space some extra TLC, tie up lose ends, and create new programming. Most importantly this campaign and your continued support allows us to continue nourishing art and artistry in all people The more money we raise, the less expensive it is for artists (and everybody!) to use the space and access the programming that we provide. 

Your Impact

This is the first step in our strategy for a sustainable Art 4 All People. You're funding the foundation of this organization and supporting it's ongoing work. The impact is huge. 

  • Together we can empower more and more people through art and the YogART way.
  • Do you believe that Art can Transform the World? It is our passion and calling.
  • Our future vision is to open a YogArt arts & healing public studio, Arts & Healing Retreat Center, and write a YogART 4 Compassion book for children. 

Risks & Challenges

  • The risks are there, and while we can't know what will happen for sure we'll do our best to meet the challenges along the way. We've have created a potent transformative arts programming. Our best assets are your support and the amazing collaboration of Ceylan and Lisa, the Co-Founding Directors & Teachers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If a monetary contribution isn't in your budget right now you can still help us by getting the word out to everybody - every share helps!

Want to get more involved at Art 4 All People? Email art4allpeople@gmail.com


Thank you for your continued inspiration and support. We bow to you with Namaste Consciousness and Gratitude. Always remember you are Art and Art is your Divine birthright.

www.art4allpeople.com

This is the first step in our strategy for a sustainable Art 4 All People. You're funding the foundation of this organization and supporting it's ongoing work. The impact is huge. 
  Together we can empower more and more people through art and the YogART way. Do you believe that Art can Transform the World? It is our passion and calling.
Our future vision is to open a YogArt arts & healing public studio, Arts & Healing Retreat Center, and write a YogART 4 Compassion book for children. 
    Risks & Challenges 
The risks are there, and while we can't know what will happen for sure we'll do our best to meet the challenges along the way. We've have created a potent transformative arts programming. Our best assets are your support and the amazing collaboration of Ceylan and Lisa, the Co-Founding Directors & Teachers. 
    Other Ways You Can Help 
If a monetary contribution isn't in your budget right now you can still help us by getting the word out to everybody - every share helps!
Want to get more involved at Art 4 All People? Email art4allpeople@gmail.com

Thank you for your continued inspiration and support. We bow to you with Namaste Consciousness and Gratitude. Always remember you are Art and Art is your Divine birthright.
www.art4allpeople.com

story:
Short Summary

Hey friends! So this is pretty straight forward: I want to upgrade from the usual heat transfer vinyl (HTV) tees to cooler screenprinted transfers. So here's the deal: 

  • The transfers have to be ordered and shipped to me
  • There is a sheet minimum per order

Because this is my first time, I want to make sure that I am not stuck with transfers that no one wants!

What We Need & What You Get

So it's simple: if this campaign can get at least 15 confirmed orders, then I will order the supplies. If not, then you keep your funds and I consider alternatives.

US only orders for now please - just to keep things simple for shipping. 
 

Risks & Challenges

The only challenges I can see are issues with the supplier, but they (Transfer Express) are a reputable company and have been around for a while now.

If this does REALLY well, there may be a slight delay in shipping. Updates will be given each step of the way.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share with your Artax-loving ffriends!

story:
ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE

As a professional landscape artist, represented in galleries in the Midwest, I am excited to receive a one month artist residency in the beautiful region of Marnay sur-Seine, France. It is located one hour south of Paris, and I will be a guest artist at Le Jardin de Botanique,  a beautiful botanical gardens located in a quaint  historic village of only 250 people. The garden is well known in France and I will be living in the garden's  little green cottage and painting and drawing en plein air for guests to watch. I also will be painting on location throughout the countryside by bicycle. I will end my stay with a gallery exhibition at the Gardens.

My flight is $1300, lodging $330, plus my food costs. I will also have material and shipping expenses, and other in-country travel expenses, for train, bus, and bicycle rental.

Although I could afford to cover this residency myself, I believe it is valuable to participate in encouraging each others gifts. I will be offering "perks" to those who support my residency and will keep you updated through my facebook artist page.

I have included the invitation letter from the Gardens.


Thank you!

Rachael Van Dyke

story:
Short Summary

I'm Casey Rocheteau, poet, historian and cartomancer. I developed the original artwork for this tarot deck in 2014. It has been accepted to art exhibits and supported by many, however, I have not been able to print the decks for public consumption. 

From it's inception, tarot has used Eurocentric images to help us predict and understand the world around us. What this deck does is modernize the tarot through both diverse representation and digital art.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need enough to fund the creation of the tarot booklet and printing the first fun of decks.
  • At bare minimum, your contribution will get your name in the booklet, because any amount helps. You also have the opportunity to receive one of the first decks and even a tarot reading from Casey.

The Impact

  • Representation in magical practice is essential. How are we expected to feel empowered by our tarot readings if they erase us?

The Impact
Representation in magical practice is essential. How are we expected to feel empowered by our tarot readings if they erase us?

story:
About Us

We are the young artist collective from Bosnia and Herzegovina formed in 2015. Our artwork is based on a specific technique of the concept street art, the wallcut as we call it. A synthesis of our initial commitments, but professions as well, where members are an architect (Muhamed Hamo Beslagic), a fine artist (Anel Lepic) and a street artist (Damir Sarac) led us to the creative vision of making a new and unique artistic expression. After working day and night and completing four large projects and exhibitions in 2015 (WALLS, Silence, Yesterday.Today!Tomorrow? and Cut in a Wall), people got interested in what we do worldwide.  The story of HAD was born from the urge to make changes alone and as a collective, breaking the habits of everyday social struggle. HAD breaks the walls they are surrounded with, and the wallcut is the tool for breaking those walls and the individual demons.

More info on our Website, Facebook and Twitter.

About Our Artwork

Our wallcut technique is based on cutting and demolition of wall surfaces, where the relations between the parts that remain and the removed parts create a relief surface of our artwork. Our work is characterized by the fact that the wall becomes the canvas, the masonry tools become the paint brush, and the wall impregnation replaces the painting binder. While leaning on the traditional methods of relief and sgraffito fresco techniques, but also traditional graphic techniques we are going in a completely different direction thematically. 

Revolutionary and selfless artistic expression, though distant from vandalism, possesses a dose of rage in itself, together with the need for stealth and a desire for change. We draw inspiration from the forgotten things, their silence, surrealism, past and melancholy, the time and place they live, turning them into representations of human figures and portraits.

Looking at the technical part of our artistic expression, we use all kinds of hard surfaces, mainly walls. We scratch, carve and engrave wall layers to achieve depth and create a form we tend to, a technique similar to woodcut and linocut. We use basic tools like hammers, chisels, knives, drills, etc. The walls which are as left behind by society and have lost their functionality as the people we put into these walls are two main points we pay our attention to.


What We Aim To 

Well, first of all we aim to spread the wallcut concept street art technique and make it available and visible to everyone. While we were creating our artworks, we were aware of the fact that you have to come to the place where it was made and see it. From the beginning, we thought what we do was different and innovative, so we wanted to show it to as much people as we can. At the opening of our first exhibition WALLS, despite the fact that the building was not safe, and there were big chances that you could get hurt, so many people came to see it that the place was crowded. That's when we came to the idea of making it accessible to everyone.
We want to show our thoughts carved in the walls, driven mostly by what's happening around everyone of us and about the things we constantly keep forgetting. 
We want to present our artworks in galleries and museums as internationally as it's possible and to achieve that we need your help.
Here is what it would look like:


What We Need

First 1000 USD will be spent on building 10 large dimension mobile walls made of masonry materials (bricks, cement, glue, mortar, plaster, calx). These are the walls we will make our wallcut artworks on. After completing them, we will be able to exhibit it worldwide in galleries, museums or any other public space. 

500 USD will be spent of masonry tools and colors (impregnations, blind frames, concrete calx colors, chisels, drilling tools, hammers, etc.)

1500 USD for the canvas prints with 10 of our previous artworks that we could exhibit just like the mobile walls and make it more accessible. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate to our project, you can still share our project on social media and along with sharing the project spread the word about us and our artwork to the people around you. We would really appreciate it.

story:
I really need your help to achieve this dream.

It may seem a bit materialistic, but it´s an indispensable tool in my daily life to do what I like.

I wish I could add money to have.

At this moment it is impossible to make that happen without your help.

I stopped doing my job and streaming mixtapes because my mixer died, help me with as you can and I promise to continue to do what I love most.


thank you for understanding

story:
Hi, my name is Drew Lemon and I am a graphic designer from San Diego, CA. I started Yes We're Open Minded because I believe people shouldn't be denied service because of who they are! I wanted to create a project from the ground up and who better to start than with artists? Join us in connecting like minded people and businesses around the world and say "Yes We're Open Minded"!

Why we need funding

  • The funding will put these signs into production and build a community driven website that commissions artists.
  • By donating you will be apart of  helping customers to identify store fronts that don't discriminate. 
  • If we do not reach our goal then we will still give all those who donated $25 or above a sign!

The Impact

With same sex marriage legal in the U.S. we still face big challenges ahead. Donating to "Yes We're Open Minded" is a positive way to stand up for equality! You will a big part of supporting artists who want to change the hearts and minds of our communities:)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us by promoting our page! 
  • Add us on Social Media!
    Instagram: yeswereopenminded
    facebook: facebook.com/yeswereopenminded
    twitter: @drewlemon
    website: yeswereopenminded.bigcartel.com







    Eduardo Recife 2015


    Matt Leines 2015


    Midnite Tremors 2015


    Cara Corder


    {ths} Thomas Schostok 2015



    Philip Morgan 2015


    Molly Mendoza 2015



         Porous Walker 2015


    Drew Lemon 2015


    Ryan Bubnis 2015
  • Ayumi Takahashi 2015


    Michael Hsiung 2015


    Alice Lancaster 2015

  • Billy Mather 2015

story:
*UPDATE*

Loss Machine was a hit in Portland, but we still need a big boost to ensure we can try something like this again...

This Project

Risk/Reward is an emerging presenter and producer of innovative live performances in Portland, Oregon. This project is a big leap forward for us in scope and ambition.

We're looking for help with Loss Machine, a gorgeous new evening length work by Seattle artist Kyle Loven to Portland. Part installation, part image-driven theater, this intimate one-man show combines puppetry, objects, light, sound, and original music in a visual exploration of loss and discovery.  It's an incredible work of art that our community deserves to experience.

Your Donation

  • The total cost for this project is about $10,000. This includes artist fees, travel, housing, venue costs, marketing, technical staff, and more. We're looking for support to cover one-quarter of that cost.
  • We believe in keeping ticket costs reasonable so that anyone can experience great art. With $20 tickets we'll still only cover half of our costs even if we sell out.
  • Your support will go directly to cover artist fees so that we can pay Kyle and his team a fair wage for their time in Portland (not to mention the months of time spent developing the performance).
  • We believe our community is willing and able to help this type of adventurous programming thrive. We want to see more performing artists in the region present their work in Portland and this project will tell us a lot about what we can support in the future.
  • Our partner and venue Artists Repertory Theater is EXTREMELY interested to see if we can pull this off successfully. If we can, who knows what might happen?
  • We're plunging into this project despite the financial uncertainty because we believe it needs to happen. Please help reward our faith in you.

The Perks

*PERKS have been updated to offer tickets to our Risk/Reward Festival in June. Come and see the next big thing!

We have several levels of support available and every contribution really makes a difference. Tickets to the show, memorabilia, special seats, free drinks, and heartfelt thanks are the simplest ways we can reward your generosity. If you've already attended Loss Machine and select a perk that includes tickets we will swap them for tickets to the 2014 Risk/Reward Festival - June 20-22, 2014. http://risk-reward.org/upcoming/2014/

Our Story

  • Since 2008, we've presented over 50 artists in our Risk/Reward Festival of New Performance. The festival acts as a catalyst to develop short new works by innovative dance, theater, music, and hard-to-define performing artists.
  • We presented a portion of Kyle's piece Moon Show 143 in the 2010 Risk/Reward Festival. We're thrilled to take this big step in helping one of our festival artists present a full-length work.
  • We're a lean, mean, DIY organization that puts every dollar we earn onstage.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Buy a ticket to the show.
  • Share this Indiegogo campaign with your friends.

Thanks so much in advance!

Short Summary

I am a Jewish Christian with the Twitter page twitter.com/@messiahcommand. These T-Shirts proclaim Yehovah (God) and Jesus (Yeshua) messages of Glory, and Greatness


What We Need & What You Get

I will use the funding to purchase more t-shirts and soon kitchen magnets. 

For a contribution of $20, you get one of these t-shirts. After you contribute, I will send you an email so you can tell me the shirt of your preference, and what size, s,m,l, extra large

The Impact

Sometimes 1 spiritual act can change the whole Earth

Risks & Challenges

There is no risk with Jesus (Yeshua).

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell friends about this, If you have a facebook page or twitter page or google+ page, please share this campaign if you believe in it.
