story:
Help LFBC spread self-published writing and independent art made by underrepresented voices 

My name is Alyssa, and I started the Letters From Bummer Camp Press & Distro in the summer of 2014 to help my peers distribute zines and other self-published work. The distro grew in size from a shoe box to a suitcase, and I went from tabling at punk shows in my basement to zine fests in major cities. It's been awesome connecting with writers and artists and helped them distribute their work through a non-capitalistic channel. Plus, more and more members of the community in New Brunswick have become engaged in self-publishing and showcasing independent artists and I hope that will continue. Print is a "dying medium" but this is way more than just getting people to read books. Self-publishing is defiant, and reading zines is radical.


2015 was a big year for LFBC. I tabled at Paper Jam at the Silent Barn in NYC, RIPExpo in Providence RI, Zine Feast at SUNY Purchase, Boston Zine Fest, local shows, poetry readings, and arts&crafts fairs. Three issues of LFBC were released this year AND we celebrated the distro's one year anniversary. Released the distro's first compilation of music, with which we raised money to fund the Reformed Church of Highland Park's initiatives to help house families of Syrian refugees.

This campaign was created to help achieve my goals for LFBC in 2016:

  • Conduct more fundraisers, but be able to reach more people with the right resources- for example, the compilation was released digitally on bandcamp, and I hope to eventually release tapes. In 2014 by selling and mailing old leftover zines to people all over the country, we raised money to go towards the Ferguson Public Library, which at the time was serving as a community space for children whose schools were closed. I would love to take on more projects like that at a greater magnitude.
  • Attend two zine fests that are not on the east coast, specifically LA and Omaha, to engage with other zinesters and community organizers living in different types of areas.
  • Turn LFBC into a subscription-based send-away mail service
  • Build a real website for the distro in order to present the project in a clear way on the internet and anyone who might be interested in participating in contributing. Right now I rely on only the Facebook and Tumblr pages to reach people and have people get in touch.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I'm capping my goal amount at $1,000 to cover the funds needed to achieve the goals stated above: travel expenses, postage, printing costs, and hiring a freelance web developer.
  • Every person who donates will get something in return, check the perks!
  • Any extra money raised will go towards local music and art spaces with similar goals and initiatives: CoLAB, In the West

The Impact

Every project within LFBC that has been launched since 2014 has been funded with extra money that I saved myself. I reimburse anyone who helps with printing, and any kind of advertising like making flyers and stickers to give out for free comes out of my own pocket. While I am happy to do this, I realize that this is holding me back from making my reach even wider. I am very grateful for all of the support and extra help I have received from other artists and writers, but at the end of the day I am the only person who runs things at LFBC. But the truth is I care less about me as a person getting recognized than my project succeeding in its mission. Money is the necessarily evil in this kind of work, because after running this zine distro for over a year I have learned that having access to resources is what keeps the distro running. With your help, I hope to print and distro as many zines as possible for as long as possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any extra money, there are always other types of ways to help out:

  • Spread the word! Repost this on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, Pinterest, Vine?!?!?

story:
GIC|SCAD is proud to announce the SCAD Illustration Anthology!

The SCAD Graduate Illustration Club fosters an active graduate community by connecting students at the Savannah College of Art and Design with industry professionals. We want to do this by creating an anthology that features work from our graduate and undergraduate students. The SCAD Illustration Anthology will be produced exclusively by SCAD students, providing professional experience and insight into the publication process. Contributors will follow the progress of the anthology as we collect submissions, advertise, and design the anthology, working as a team to produce the book. The GIC|SCAD officers and project creators will facilitate the process:

President: Rae Cook
Vice President: Jacqueline Juretus
Treasurer: Alexa Dubus
Secretary: Steph Bral
Communications: Alejo Porras

Let’s help the SCAD community leave a lasting impression!
Our goal is to  bridge the gap between student and industry professional by producing a publication and getting it to into the hands of art directors. The SCAD Illustration Anthology will be released and available to purchase at the Illustration EXPO, a popular artist market event hosted by GIC|SCAD on May 6, 2016. This event also aligns with Art Directors week at SCAD, which means artists in the SCAD Illustration Anthology and at the EXPO will have a chance to show their work and speak with art directors. Part of the Indiegogo funding will allow us to reserve and provide a number of anthologies as take-aways for visiting art directors. 

What We Need & What You Get

What will your benevolent contributions go towards?

  • Pre-press production: This includes any design consultations we might need outside of our volunteer efforts, and any file-prep printer fees.
  • Printing: We want to support local business.
  • Packaging: This will cover any extra supplies for packaging and storage of books.
  • Shipping: No brainer here. We have to pay to move these babies.
  • Art Director copies: We want to set aside a number of copies for visiting art directors and send some copies out to relevant art directors in the United States.

We have some excellent perks lined up!
Every little bit counts, so we want to say thanks to everyone by putting each and every contributor's name on a special thank you page within the Illustration Anthology. From there, the perks just get better and better. They include digital copies, early bird and discounted orders, t-shirts, and artist prints! 

The Impact

Professional art directories are very helpful tools for Art Directors and other hiring professionals. This initiative is a great way to showcase our collective talent and help students establish contacts that could have a positive impact on their careers. The SCAD Illustration Anthology will be produced by a key team of students who will use their individual skills to produce a high-quality, professional directory. This is invaluable experience for those volunteering to make this Anthology the best it can be!

The History of the Graduate Illustration Club
The Graduate Illustration Club has worked hard to have a positive impact on the community by giving SCAD students opportunities to interact with others and contribute their skills. Here are a few examples of what GIC|SCAD has contributed:

  • First Annual Illustration EXPO: A student artist market focused on illustration open to students and the public.
  • Best New Club 2015: Awarded by the SCAD InterClub Council.
  • Live Interview Series: GIC|SCAD hosts bi-weekly live interviews with industry professionals working in illustration.
  • Community Volunteering: Masquerade Ball Photo Booth, event monitoring.

Risks & Challenges

The Anthology is primarily intended to be promotional material for our graduate illustration students. It’s vital that we get this important book into the right hands!

Time is ticking.
The Anthology will be completed in time for our 2nd Annual Illustration EXPO on May 6, 2016. This is an opportunity to not only showcase our work to the public, but also to possible future employers and art directors! The sooner we are able to get the necessary financing, the sooner we’re able to get the ball rolling on printing the Anthologies. In the meantime, we will provide regular updates on the submission and design process.

We’re ready whenever you are, and we’re excited to get everyone their copies! 

What if we don't make our printing goal?

  • All contributors that donated over $10 will receive a complete digital version of the SCAD Illustration Anthology.
  • Don't worry, all other perks will remain the same.

Other Ways You Can Help!

You have a huge impact on the success of our Anthology, and every contribution, like, and share counts! We encourage you to get the word out about this project - let's make some noise about our campaign.

story:
Short Summary

When writing my book The Signature of all Things, I knew from the start that I wanted to base the Whittakers in Philadelphia, and I dreamt of them living in a vast, palatial estate (graced with gardens and greenhouses) on the Schuylkill River. But I also wanted the novel to be plausible, so I went searching about to see if, in fact, there had ever been any vast palatial estates (graced with gardens and greenhouses) built on the Schuylkill River. To my delight, I stumbled upon The Woodlands, which became the wonderful model for my novel’s fictitious estate, White Acre.

So much of The Woodlands ended up in my novel — providing me with marvelous details which, I believe, help the book spring to life. I was so impressed by the carriage house, for instance, that I gave it a central role in my narrative. (Alma Whittaker, my heroine, has her private botanical study there.)

The Woodlands has now become so intrinsically entwined in my mind with White Acre that I can scarcely tell the two apart. I’ve been so grateful, as well, to the welcome that the curators of this great American treasure have given me — to the grounds, to the rooms, to the history. My hope is that my imagined story will draw very real readers to this very real place, so that The Woodlands will continue to get the appreciation it so richly deserves! The Woodlands needs our help NOW, to preserve the Mansion and Carriage House for the future.  I will be donating to this great cause myself, but I'm hoping my fans and readers will help The Woodlands to raise an additional 50,000 for preservation.

Why should The Woodlands Mansion and Carriage House be restored? 

  • Every aspect of The Woodlands (mansion, carriage house, and grounds) is historically significant to the nation, not just to Philadelphia. This project will restore them to the grandeur of Alma’s day.
  • There are more people using The Woodlands today than ever before, and they are using it in many more ways. It is a place of true exploration, discovery and inspiration. 
  • Once the mansion and carriage house are restored, they will house classrooms, workshop space, and allow more people to access this amazing place.  

What are the steps involved in restoration? 

Mansion
  • Wood and Window Conservation
  • Painting
  • Iron railing restoration
  • Portico stone pavers and lighting

Carriage House 

  • Wood and Window Conservation
  • Masonry Repairs
  • Electrical service and exterior lighting

The full restoration cost of both buildings will be $830,400.

The William B. Dietrich Foundation has pledged $612,000 to restore the mansion if The Woodlands can raise an additional $218,400 to restore the carriage house. We have to raise this money by January 31, 2015 in order to get the funds. With your help, we can restore these treasures!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • share this campaign with your friends
  • share this campaign via social media
  • visit The Woodlands website and consider becoming a member of this amazing organization.

story:
Help us bring 4 fire-powered cannons and a custom target shooting range out to the Playa!

 


Step right up! Take a shot – I dare you!

BOOM! Your attention is awakened as you hear the loud call of the Fireball Shooting Gallery echo out across the Playa. BOOM! BOOM! Before you even know it you are on a quest to find the source of this insane noise. As the dust clears, there it is – a lone carnival shooting booth calling to you to “take a shot”.

Bay Area metal and fire artist, Al Stahler, along with his team of fatuous x-treme elves, have a fun project that we are bringing out to the Playa this year – but we can only do it with the help and support of you, our community!


  


The Fireball Shooting Gallery will give you the opportunity to personally load, charge, and fire one of 4 propane-fired tennis ball cannons at a custom-built range of moving and stationary targets. Expect fire! Expect mayhem! Expect to be scared at first, and then excited to try it again and again!  



We need your support

We are raising funds to cover the costs of materials including of lumber, lighting, hardware, tubing, paint and propane, as well as transportation to the playa.  All the money raised will go directly towards the purchasing of the materials needed to bring this project to life.  Every little bit helps – even $5 donations can help ensure we get the Fireball Shooting Gallery out to the Playa for you to experience and enjoy! 


The Crew

Al Stahler is the mastermind behind this fun and interactive project.  He has worked on numerous projects from the Bliss Dance Crew, Celtic Forest, Heartfullness, Paha'oha'o and Last Flame Thrower Crew.

He is supported by a small yet mighty crew that love helping him create his fire magic.




A couple of the fun perks available!


Carnival Party Popper

Al's Carnival Party Popper. Your own personal flaming popper. A spark and a pop that will delight fire enthusiasts, yet easy enough for a novice to operate.

Check out a demonstration here.

Custom Flask

Your very own flask with the Fireball Shooting Gallery logo on it.  Always have your favorite spirit in your back pocket or purse. 


Aluminum Shot Glasses

2oz Custom Shot glasses in Fireball red!




Crew Bandana

The official red Fireball Shooting Gallery crew bandana. Made especially for YOU by our crew! A must need item on the playa - cover your face in the dust or show your flair by wearing it in your hair!



Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word and make some noise about our project.  We also are looking for in-kind donations of construction materials such as lumber, pallets, nails, lighting and of course help with the building process too.
story_txt:
Help us bring 4 fire-powered cannons and a custom target shooting range out to the Playa! Step right up! Take a shot – I dare you!BOOM! Your attention is awakened as you hear the loud call of the Fireball Shooting Gallery echo out across the Playa. BOOM! BOOM! Before you even know it you are on a quest to find the source of this insane noise. As the dust clears, there it is – a lone carnival shooting booth calling to you to “take a shot”.Bay Area metal and fire artist, Al Stahler, along with his team of fatuous x-treme elves, have a fun project that we are bringing out to the Playa this year – but we can only do it with the help and support of you, our community!  The Fireball Shooting Gallery will give you the opportunity to personally load, charge, and fire one of 4 propane-fired tennis ball cannons at a custom-built range of moving and stationary targets. Expect fire! Expect mayhem! Expect to be scared at first, and then excited to try it again and again!  We need your supportWe are raising funds to cover the costs of materials including of lumber, lighting, hardware, tubing, paint and propane, as well as transportation to the playa.  All the money raised will go directly towards the purchasing of the materials needed to bring this project to life.  Every little bit helps – even $5 donations can help ensure we get the Fireball Shooting Gallery out to the Playa for you to experience and enjoy! 
The CrewAl Stahler is the mastermind behind this fun and interactive project.  He has worked on numerous projects from the Bliss Dance Crew, Celtic Forest, Heartfullness, Paha'oha'o and Last Flame Thrower Crew.He is supported by a small yet mighty crew that love helping him create his fire magic.


A couple of the fun perks available!

Carnival Party Popper
Al's Carnival Party Popper. Your own personal flaming popper. A spark and a pop that will delight fire enthusiasts, yet easy enough for a novice to operate.
Check out a demonstration here.












Custom Flask

Your very own flask with the Fireball Shooting Gallery logo on it.  Always have your favorite spirit in your back pocket or purse. 










Aluminum Shot Glasses
2oz Custom Shot glasses in Fireball red!
Crew BandanaThe official red Fireball Shooting Gallery crew bandana. Made especially for YOU by our crew! A must need item on the playa - cover your face in the dust or show your flair by wearing it in your hair!



Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word and make some noise about our project.  We also are looking for in-kind donations of construction materials such as lumber, pallets, nails, lighting and of course help with the building process too.

story:
The campaign has ended and we are so thankful for everyone that made us exceed our target. Pleaae check www.focusofachild.com for continued updates.



In India:

  • 1 in 6 girls have a chance of not seeing their 15th birthday,
  • The UN has named the country one of the most dangerous places in the world for a girl to grow up,
  • Less than half of the females will have a chance to attend secondary school.
  • Over half of the girls will get married before they are old enough to finish school.
  • There are over 500,000 underaged girls working in the commercial sex trafficking industry.

Camera’s for kids is just one component of the brand new arts program, Focus of a Child that will be kicking off in October 2016 in Kolkata India.  Research has found that regardless of culture, social status or economic well being, when children are exposed to the arts they stay in school longer, their communication skills accelerate, and their self worth/value skyrockets.  The list actually goes on with over 100 benefits from exposure to the arts.

Focus of a Child will be bringing the art of photography to two groups of students in Howrah India, a slum area on the outskirts of downtown Kolkata.  Three internationally acclaimed photographers will be teaching students not just the technical side of photography but they will allow the students to discover the true art of photography.  Soon the students will begin to see their world through a new lens. One that will spark creativity, joy and give them a new source of communication.

The initial roll out of the Focus of a Child program will include two groups of children. The first will be a group of 25 students attending HB school in Howrah that will consist of children, mostly females ranging from 12-15.  This is a true make it or break it time in an Indian child’s life.  Being involved in the arts can be a major catalyst to a child “making it” Our second group of children consists of 6 daughters of parents who currently are working in the commercial sex trade industry.  These girls are at a critical tipping point in their life.  Gaining new skills, self confidence and pride for their family can give them the opportunity to break the family cycle of being a prisoner in the life crushing sex trade industry.

 A camera WILL make a difference. YOU can make a difference.  We need your help to impact a student by providing support in obtaining the cameras needed for each student.  Your donation will give each student the opportunity to have a personal camera that they can use during the program.  If we make our goal the students will be able to bring home their camera and tell THEIR story through the images they will capture each evening and will not need to share the camera with other students.   

You have the opportunity to put a camera into the hands of a child. Your gift, your thoughtful gesture, can unlock the gate of hope for many, trapped in a world of hopeless poverty. Your donation will make this a reality. Imagine the joy that a camera will bring to each child; enabling them to gain new skills, increase self-confidence; and experience a new found self-worth.

Our Purpose

To Teach

You have the opportunity to partner with three photographers as they introduce the world of photography to two different groups of children in Kolkata India.  

The first group of children is connected to an established local group that works with children trapped in a life within the “red-light” brothel district.  The second group is of young eager students attending HCS Elementary School in the Pikhana slums of Kolkata, once made famous as being the backdrop for the movie "the City of Joy".

To Train

Not only will we be teaching the children, we will also be training local teachers to be able to continue this project. We believe the arts have a way of grabbing hold of a child and giving them a creative outlet, an escape, a voice.

To Empower

It has been said, "A child trained and educated in the arts changes themselves, their family, their community and even the world".  We want to empower each child within this program with the ability to positively impact themselves and others around them. 


What We Need

Engagement

  • We are looking to raise $5000.00 to provide cameras for the children. 
  • Each of these cameras will be used by multiple students.
  • A gallery exhibition of the children's photography works is scheduled in Kolkata at the end of the program. Funds raised in excess of our goal will help cover the expense of printing and framing of the children's artwork. 

Impact

  • Your generous donation will provide a camera to a child.  Imagine the joy that a simple camera will bring to each child.
  • The children will gain new skills, build self-confidence and experience a new found self-worth.
  • It is proven that exposure to the arts helps advance a child's education.  Poor education is a problem around the globe, be part of the solution! 
  • Photography will allow these children to express and tell their stories with the power to truly move people.
Risks & Challenges

We cannot be successful in working with these kids without the right tools. With or without the help of others we will be heading to India to start this program. Please help us achieve our goal.

  • The better the tools the better we can serve these kids.
  • Our biggest challenge will be accommodating the large number of children waiting for this program.
Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please help spread the word and make some noise about our campaign!

We thank you for helping us shape the focus of a child!


The Team

Sarah - 

She’s a dreamer, traveler and championne.  She’s also a photographer.  Prefers real moments, genuine people, hearing long life stories over libations and is rapt with the desire to create honest emotive imagery that transcends time.

An International award winning photographer, her work has been published in the New York Times, VANITY FAIR, Under the Gum Tree and Paris Lit Up.  She began her work in 2005 and specializes in wedding, portrait and fine art commissions. 

When she isn't traversing the globe she can be found in Oakland, California. http://www.sarahdawson.net/

Steve - 
Steve is an accomplished and published photographer with 30 years behind the lens. His images have been found in many of the top music magazines, Album covers and artwork, newspapers and online throughout the web. Steve’s ability to capture emotion at just the right moment has allowed him to travel the world as a humanitarian project photographer for both World Vision, and Compassion International, two of the largest humanitarian relief organizations.

Steve is a husband to one, father of two and a friend of many. He resides in Granite Bay California, with his wife and two daughters. 
www.studio5300.com 

Mark - 

Mark has been shooting high-quality photographs for over twenty years. Always interested in teaching others the art of good photography, he began conducting workshops emphasizing the various aspects of photography. These workshops have now been attended by thousands of amateur and professional photographers from around the world. As well, he reaches thousands of photographers through his website, www.Lightingasylum.com.

When not working in the studio or conducting workshops throughout the United States, Mark spends most of his free time with his wife and their four children. Together, they enjoy boating, camping, hiking and riding quads in the mountains near their home in Redding, California.

                                                       

Cameras for kids is a project of Zedbridge, a 501(c)3 non profit organization.  Zedbridge's mission is help underprivileged children escape the bonds of poverty and hopelessness by providing education, life skills, values, a caring and safe environment.  To empower them to successfully move into the mainstream of society, have active and creative minds, a sense of understanding and compassion for others, and the courage to act on their beliefs. www.zedbridge.org

All donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law

story:
I'm seeking your support to take my mobile art show to the next level.  I've been a painter my whole life, in and out of galleries, and always improving my work. Last year I decided to take control of the marketing of my work. I made the commitment to selling my art at outdoor markets.  It went pretty well.  I learned a lot about selling my work and new, more affordable types of art products I could create and offer.  I also learned that I needed to do a lot more art fairs in different locations.

But as with all businesses, there are a lot of up-front costs involved with participating in the art market scene.  From jury fees, to artists association fees, to business licenses for each town, to booth fees, to gas, to food and lodging – it mounts up quickly.

That's where you come in.  With this indiegogo campaign I'm hoping to raise at least $1500 to help with these upfront costs.  In the past artists looked to wealthy patrons for support.  I find these times of crowdsourcing and social networking so exciting as it opens up the world of patronage to regular working folks. As a supporter you become like a modern-day Medici, helping an artist (me) continue to create and share my work with the world.
 
But why would you want to support my work.  Well, In this crazy world I continue to believe in the power of beauty and love to transform.   I guess that's why I keep on doing what I do.  It is my hope that my art contributes to this energy, and supports and expresses a world view, based on harmony, love, cooperation and interconnectedness.  

What do you get in return for your support.  Just look to the right of my project page and you'll see the different levels of support and all the different art products available for each level.  From greeting cards, to miniature canvasses, to little hand-painted boxes, to my journal for your own creative work, to giclee prints, original art, and commissioned work there are many options from which to choose.

I would be so very grateful for any and all support you can offer.  Even if you can't offer monetary support at this time, it would be wonderful if you could pass the word on to your friends about my campaign.  Thanks a lot and maybe I'll see you at one of the markets.
 
Commission your pastel portrait.

story:
Meisterausstellung


Die Prüfung ist in drei Hauptteile gegliedert. Einen Teil umfasst die praktische Prüfung, die mit einer Ausstellung gekrönt wird.  Die Ausstellung wird am 19/20 Juli 2014 statt finden. Für diesen Teil darf ich 5 florale Gestaltungen kreieren. Unteranderem befasse ich mich mit einem Blumenstrauss, einem Kranz und Brautschmuck. Zudem werden diese 5 floralen Gestaltungen in 20m2 ausgestellt. Hierfür werde ich einen stabilen Standaufbau bauen der mit gutem Licht und wertvollen Materialien ausgestattet ist.

Warum brauche ich deine Hilfe

Ich bin noch jung und erst seit kurzem im Berufsleben. Ich liebe meinen Beruf auch wenn man keine finanziellen Hochsprünge machen kann. Die Meisterschule und insbesondere die Prüfung kosten mich einen hübschen Haufen Geld, welchen ich alleine nicht stemmen kann. Deine Unterstützung kann ich bei meinen 5 Gestaltungen gut gebrauchen, so werde ich gutes Licht installieren, schöne florale Werkstoffe verarbeiten und eine tolle Ausstellungsfläche aufbauen.

Für deine nette Unterstützung schenke ich dir tolle Perks wie zum Beispiel Eintritte zu meiner Ausstellung, persönliche Erläuterung meiner Gestaltungen oder blumige Überraschungen.

Und noch zum Schluss

Du findest mein Projekt Hammer aber leider hast du nicht das nötige Kleingeld um mich zu unterstützen. Halb so wild, es ist mir auch eine grosse Hilfe wenn du von meinem Vorhaben weiter erzählst. Je mehr Menschen von meinem Projekt wissen, desto mehr Menschen können mich unterstützen.

Ich bedanke mich für deine Neugierde und deine Zeit!

story:
Short Summary

Our wellness and healing candle line will help people keep their fire burning and lights shining brightly! We are counselors by training and healers by heart. When we discovered the power of our own healing and growth, we were moved to share it with the world. One of our company goals is to create a big sister/little sister mentorship program to introduce and reinforce the conversation of self love, self care and healing. Your contributions will help us secure a larger production space and spaces to host healing workshops. We are all on this journey of growth and healing together.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $2,000 to secure a creative production space as we currently are limited to our homes and this space will allow us the opportunity to produce more candles at a faster rate. Check out the perks, you will like them! We welcome all levels of contributions from $5 to $500.

The Impact

Our candle company is committed to sharing our passion for personal growth and healing with the world.Through our contribution young girls and women will have the opportunity to discover self care and practice self love and healing. We desire to increase conversation and awareness around personal growth and development through this amazing product.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please remember to share our campaign with your networks of friends, family and coworkers by using the Indiegogo share tools.

We desire to increase conversation and awareness around personal growth and development through this amazing product.Other Ways You Can HelpPlease remember to share our campaign with your networks of friends, family and coworkers by using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
On September 15, 2013, around 04:30 am, A small historic shopping center in Pasadena was heavily damaged by a devastating fire (Here is the link to the news report and video: http://ktla.com/2013/09/15/flames-damage-a-strip-mall-in-pasadena/#axzz2f1HLMRtw). 


One of the spaces that suffered heavy damage was an artist studio belonging to my dear and close friend Nalani Hernandez-Melo. Her studio is now gone, along with a large body of work, equipment, artists supplies, and personal items. This was such a tragic event to happen to such a wonderful person. For those who don't know Nalani; Nalani is a kind and generous person. She is quick to lend a helping hand, and a very loyal friend. Nalani is also one of the most hardworking people I know. She juggles multiple hats and jobs, working in fine art, printmaking, graphic design, and film production.


I started this campaign to help provide some financial relief to Nalani. Currently, the estimated damage in Nalani's Art Studio is $10,000, this campaign is just a small start to what we can do to help. My goal is to exceed the $500 goal. All of the proceeds will go to helping Nalani purchase new art supplies and equipment, so she can continue working and produce more art. So with the kindness of your heart, please donate whatever you can to help a wonderful person in a time of need. Nalani is a talented interdisciplinary artist, and a wonderful human being, and I know if I was ever in this situation she would've done whatever she could to help out.  


Photos of the damage.

Some of Nalani's Work

story:
About the project

People can have many pets, but each owner means the the whole world to the pet. They deserve to be remembered because I guarantee they’ll always remember you. That’s why I started this project. I want to draw your beloved friend a portrait with the date you met and the day he/she left written on the side. I want you to recall the happy times you’ve spent together whenever you looked at the portrait after he/she left. 

The inspiration for this project comes from several failed attempts to own a pet. I once had a black poodle and two cats when I was in college. My first cat “puppy” was with me for 52 days. Since having a pet in the dorm was not allowed, I had to give her away eventually. I then met my second cat, "Wasabi" during junior year. Wasabi was with me for quite sometime. I used to take her with me on the train ride back home. She grew so big at the end of the vacation that I couldn’t take her with me on the train anymore. Luckily, a friend of my mom who really loved the cat adopted her. I still remember the day we parted. I cried so hard and couldn’t stop thinking about the happy times we had together. She used to hang herself upside down on the  bed side begging me to go to bed with her. Sometimes she would sleep in my backpack when I went out and would stick her head out to enjoy the street views.

 “Mimi” was a black poodle. Though I made up my mind after “Puppy” and “Wasabi” that I was not going to have a pet during college anymore, I had to adopt Mimi because a friend in college decided to discard him. This was my first and last time raising a dog. It’s true what everyone says about dogs – that they’re truly man’s best friend and loyal beyond belief. When the time came for him to leave, I felt like I lost a friend. Someone who really understood  me. Fortunately, Mimi was adopted by a really nice lady and lives a happy life.  

As much as I loved Puppy, Wasabi and Mimi, I know the image of them is fading away everyday since they left. As the days pass their image continues to flicker away in my memory until it seems as if they had never came into my life.

About me 


My name is Lalla Zhang. I’m an independent illustrator from China. I’ve received hundreds of photos of pets from their owners after I started this project in China. I just held the “Companions for Life” art exhibition in June this year, and have published “Companions for Life” postcards.

       Hand drawn portrait of golden retriever "fuzzy" from the campaign in China



I now “serve” three cats in my little apartment. “Niu Niu”, “Smelly-smell”, “Shinny Bean”

                                              "Niu Niu" and "Smelly-smell"

                                                          “Shinny Bean"


Niu niu and Smelly-smell are a couple. I bought them from a grandpa selling pets under a bridge on a rainy evening. They were less than a month old when I brought them home. I had to feed them with cotton swab dipped in milk until they were old enough to eat cat food. They’ve been living with me for two years. I adopted Shinny bean less than half a year ago.

Each one of my three little babies has a distinct personality. Smelly-smell is peaceful and loves lazing around. He enjoys taking pictures a lot. Niu niu wouldn’t leave me out of sight and has to sleep in my arm.  Shinny bean is a little timid. She tends to overact to anyone or anything approaching her.

As an independent illustrator, I work in my apartment and tend to stay up late finishing projects. So I can say my only daily companions are my three babies. To me, they are like family. Them being there every night when I’m working means a great deal to me. To show my gratitude, I always buy snacks and canned tuna for them.   


How it works? 

I started this project on Indiegogo because I want to know about the stories between owners and their pets around the world. If you would like me to draw a portrait of your pet and share your story with fellow animal lovers, please support $80, $200 or $250, and email the following to zhanglalla@outlook.com

1.  Pictures of your pet (high-resolution please)

2.  The time period he/she stayed with you (e.g. 2012.12.12--2013.12.6)

3.  If you don’t mind, please share with me the stories between you and your pet.  Like any interesting anecdote and why you two parted. With your consent, I'll share the stories in my next exhibition or publish them together with the portrait of your pets in a book 

4.  A sentence you really want to say to him/her (no more than 20 words)

5.  Your Indiegogo account name



What I want to do with the fund raised?

1. “Companion for Life” is what I want to do with my life. As long as people are sending me pictures/stories of their pets and donations, the “Companion for Life” project can be going on forever! It usually takes me more than two days to finish a portrait. Therefore, the donation will be used to cover the basic costs, and my living expenses.

2. The donation will help me to hold four more “Companion for Life” exhibitions in China and possibly a tour exhibition in the U.S:)  I plan to hold an exhibition in different cities once a year. My first exhibition was held in Xi’an city, because I went to college in Xi’an and still lives there. I want to hold my second exhibition in Guangzhou, where many of my childhood friends live. Their job has nothing to do with what they dream of doing. I want to encourage them and show them that dreams do come true. Afterwards, I want to hold exhibitions in Beijing and Shanghai, because that’s where all the artists and dreamers are. I’ll pick a small, quiet and artistic city for my last exhibition. If possible, I’ll leave all my works there forever.

3. I also want to publish a book with drawings of all your pets and stories. I want to share all the stories I’ve collected with people around the world. 


                                    Published "Companions for Life" post cards

                                         Colored pencil I use to draw the portrait 



Portraits from the last campaign

story:
(English below)

Soy Juan Felipe Mejia Tobon, baterista, percusionista y compositor de Bogotá, Colombia.

Ha sido un largo y emocionante camino desde que empecé a tocar música. He vivido en diferentes lugares del mundo y he conocido gente de muchas culturas con la que he tenido el placer de tocar.

La música es mi pasión, es lo que me mantiene vivo y feliz.

Hace dos años vivo en Boston, EE.UU., y estudio en Berklee College of Music, gracias a una beca de la universidad y el generoso apoyo de mi familia, en este tiempo he estado trabajando en un proyecto muy especial e importante para mi, se llama Juan Mejia's Conspiracy. Soy el compositor de toda la música, toco batería y dirijo la banda, es mi forma de expresarme a través de la música. He tenido la suerte de encontrar excelentes músicos de todo el mundo que hacen parte de este proyecto y que entienden lo que quiero expresar a través de la música que escribo.

Actualmente estoy en una de las etapas mas importantes como músico, he logrado grabar mi primer EP (un disco con 6 canciones) como líder de mi banda, hay 2 procesos adicionales por los que tienen que pasar las grabaciones para que puedan ser terminadas y publicadas. Los procesos son la mezcla y la masterización, estos  son hechos por un ingeniero de mezcla y masterización.

Quiero invitarlos a ser parte de mi camino como músico y a apoyarme para   terminar la mezcla y masterización de mi disco, los procesos por los que tiene que pasar antes de ser terminado tienen costos muy altos además de los costos de el arte del disco y de las copias físicas. 

Espero contar con su apoyo para terminar mi proyecto y así compartirlo, espero que mi música les guste y la disfruten tanto como yo disfruto al crearla.

juanmejiamusic.com

facebook.com/juanmejiamusic

youtube.com/watch?v=pKTa4zqKZrw

My name is Juan Mejia, I am a drummer, percussionist and composer from Bogotá, Colombia.

It's been an exiting journey since I started playing music. I have lived in different cities of the world, I have met people from different cultures and I have had the pleasure of performing with/for them. 

Music is my passion, it is what makes me want to wake up every morning, what keeps me alive and happy. 

For the past 2 years, while living in Boston, USA, and while attending Berklee College of Music with a generous scholarship from the college, I have been working on a very special project called Juan Mejia's Conspiracy. I write all the music, play drums and direct the band and it is a way for me to express myself through music. I have been lucky enough to find not only amazing musicians but amazing people from all over the world that are part of this project and that really understand what I want to express with my compositions.

I am currently in the most important moment of my career as a musician, my first EP as a band leader has been recorded. In order to release my EP there are 2 processes that the recordings have to go through; mixing, and mastering. These 2 have to be done by professional engineers.

I want to invite you to be part of my journey and to help me finish my project, the costs of the mixing and mastering processes are very high, along with the costs of the cover art, and the copies of the CDs.

Thank you very much!

story:
Would you trust a ten-year-old to cut your hair?

Haircuts by Children (HBC) trains 5th graders to cut hair, and then, in partnership with a salon, the children offer free haircuts to any interested adult as a two-day performance. HBC is a whimsical performance that playfully engages with the enfranchisement of children; trust in the younger generation, and the thrills and chills of vanity. HBC invites the consideration of children as creative and competent individuals whose aesthetic choices can be trusted.

 

Fusebox is bringing this unique performance to Austin in November 2011, to give at-risk youth access to an experience that will give them a better understanding of themselves as confident and creative individuals. Trust from an adult stranger is empowering for children; and this project can give children the self-confidence to make positive, constructive, decisions. 

 

The students will train everyday after school for one week with professional artists and hairstylists. Following the training, the performances will take place at the Peacock Salon on E. Cesar Chavez on Saturday November 12 and Sunday November 13 for four hours each day. After the weekend performance, the youth will reconvene with the artists, the students’ teacher, and hair stylists reflect on the experience.

 

The performance is free and open to the general public of all ages, although the free haircuts will only be given to consenting adults on a first come-first serve basis. Participation in the project is free for the students, but parental consent is required. The students will perform every role in the salon, rotating between jobs of managing reservations, cutting hair, and operating a lemonade stand where 100% of the profits will go to charity or project of the students’ choosing.

 

Canadian performance company Mammalian Dive Reflex (MDR) developed HBC in 2006. Since its introduction, the work has been presented over 50 times, to critical acclaim, all over the world including Canada, Australia, Ireland, UK, Italy, Los Angeles, New York City, and Portland, Oregon. 


What We Need

Your financial contributions will directly support the following:

  • Provide transportation for the participating students,
  • Help Fusebox purchase necessary supplies for the training workshops, and
  • Provide stipends to the students.


Fusebox needs your help to make sure Haircuts By Children reaches as many youth in our community as possible. the project can accommodate up to 50 students. To reach the goal of 50 5th graders, Fusebox is partnering with two of east Austin's most underprivileged schools: Pecan Springs and Norman Elementary schools. Because we are working with multiple schools Fusebox will need to rent vans to shuttle students to and from the after school workshops and weekend performances.


Secondly, Fusebox needs support for purchasing supplies for the training and performances. Critical supplies like mannequin heads ("Judys"), spray bottles, clips, hair product, brushes, combs, etc. are essential (and more expensive than you might think).


Finally, the students are paid $10 for each haircut they complete over the two day performance. This is an important element of the project because it places tangible value on the work, and aesthetics, of the children. The haircuts are free for adult clients, so Fusebox will pay the youth directly. 


What You Get

Contributions of any size are a huge help and appreciated, but as added perks, Fusebox is offering some special incentives for larger gifts like free shirts, priority scheduling and tickets to great events. Details are to the right.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out about this wonderful project and our modest fundraising campaign! Social media, talk it up at parties, write thoughtful letters to family and friends.


Also - if you have leads on getting vans or some of the supplies donated - thats as good as a cash contribution - let us know!

story:
(Above image by Federico TBN)

Short Summary

The Asiatown Print Shop is a silkscreen studio that will be silkscreening original artworks LIVE on the playa at Burningman.  You bring us your shirt, pants, jacket, shorts etc and we will silkscreen it and hand it back to you on the spot so you can have fancy fresh artwork on your playa wear! We will even have black light reactive ink to use!  

This is the inaugural year of the Print Shop and we need your help getting the supplies we need in order to make this a somewhat smooth operation in the dusty dusty desert.

Asiatown Print Shop is part of the French Quarter and will be located within the back alleys of the French Quarter (730 & B) in Black Rock Asiatown.  We will have rotating designs from an ever growing library of original art work that we hope to continue building upon in future years.

Artists who design artwork for the Print Shop retain all copyrights for their work, and all imagery is printed only on the playa.

I set the goal a bit low, but...
We Need Approximately $1,580.

This will cover:
- One 4-color tabletop printing press - $450
- Screens, ink, emulsion, soy based cleaner, squeegees, plastic bins etc - $350
- Electricity for the heating element to cure the ink and light for the shop - $150
- Shop lights and bulbs - $70
- Two 8ft folding tables - $250  
- Heavy duty garbage bags and plastic sheeting to protect screens - $50
- Costco car port to set up the shop in  - $230
- Tarp for the bottom of the Costco car port  - $30

What You Get:
With contributions of varying degrees, you will get a patch, tote bag, t-shirt, or sweatshirt printed on the playa, with original artwork from the Asiatown Print Shop and sent to wherever you are located!  
Contributors at any level get access to secret screens on the playa with a super secret password :-)


The Impact
Last year was my first time at Burningman.  I joined the Golden Cafe and French Quarter camps and was blown away by how many incredible projects were housed within them (a bakery, a voodoo botanica, a live jazz band, a coffee house that roasts raw beans on playa, a gumbo cookery, a vineyard, a brewery, a supper club, a bathhouse, a wine cellar, a ramshackle whiskey bar, an elegant cocktail lounge, a farmer's market, and a hotel).  I was a bar back in the Golden Cafe, but wanted to do more than hang out in the bar serving drinks.  I wanted to produce something that could be taken home with people and cherished, or gifted.  

Since I have a lot of experience with silkscreening and have some supplies already, I decided to bring my skills out this year with a silkscreen shop, in addition to tending bar at the Golden Cafe. 

With the Print Shop, I hope to contribute to the participatory aspects of Burningman, as well as develop a library of original artwork images that the Print Shop will be able to pull from in future years, and which will be printed only on the playa.    

We will also be collecting garments to silkscreen during Print Shop down time so that we have some ready to wear garments if anyone needs any.

No Water!
We will be using only plastisol inks which means we will not be using any water at all in the printing process, and the inks will not dry in the screens rendering them useless.  

We will use only soy based cleaners to minimize toxic odors.



Other Ways You Can Help
- Please spread the word and help us get contributions!!
- Are you going to be at Burning Man??
You can volunteer to work at the Print Shop while you are there! We will be open once the sun starts going down and will need help printing and curing the ink.  Please email Ashira at BurnPrintShop@gmail.com
- Are you an artist?  You can donate artwork to be printed on the playa (subject to curating).  Artwork MUST be original.  You retain copyright but give us permission to reproduce as needed on the playa.
- You can also donate (clean) shirts and jackets, plastisol inks, aluminum screens and any of the equipment listed above!

story:
Be the next person to grab an incentive valued at $100 or above and receive one gift certificate for 2 free 30-minute personal training sessions.


And you don't have to be a member!

 

PS:Predicament

PS:Gallery is a small commercial art gallery in Columbia Missouri.  Over the past eight years, it has served as a cornerstone to the city's culture, representing artists and various art-related events with a gallery space that is free and open to the public.  Recently the owners announced plans to relocate to Denver, Colorado.  Without adequate funding, the gallery will unfortunately be forced to close its doors.  Joel Sager, who has served as curator and permanent artist since the gallery's inception, is leading efforts with the staff to keep it alive.  But, at this pivotal point we need your help.  

We know that visual art enriches a community.  This enrichment comes with a price and countless people have stepped forward to chip in.  This Indiegogo campaign is a platform to concentrate those financial efforts no matter how big or small.  Reaching our goal of $40,000 will aid in the transition and sustain this vital arts establishment.  We're turning to you, our strongest allies, to ask for help in realizing this goal.  In exchange for your support, a number of our represented artists have generously provided work as incentives for your contribution.  Not to mention all kinds of PS:Gallery swag, loads of Sparky's Homemade Ice Cream, tickets to performing arts, and tons more!  Your contribution will help us continue the work of highlighting artists from across the country, and nurture this visual arts gallery that is essential to our community.

 

PS:Advocacy

 

PS:Crew 

Here are the faces of this campaign.  Joel Sager is leading efforts to keep the gallery doors open with the assistance of Amy Meyer, Jonny Pez, and Antoine Matondo.

 

PS:Community Impact

For close to a decade, PS:Gallery has been a crucial fixture, providing opportunities to foster the exhibition of contemporary art and the exchange of its ideas.  The community regularly gathers here, whether it be for one of the 100+ artists the gallery has represented, for Artrageous Fridays (a nonprofit quarterly gallery crawl founded in conjunction with other downtown establishments), or for one of the dozens of annual philanthropic events hosted in our space.  With thousands of dollars raised comprehensively for these charities and aiding in the subsidization of countless artists work, no community institution paints with as broad a brush these all-encompassing cultural foundational services.  It is essential to be kept alive. 

 

PS:Support

There are three important ways to lend a hand in our efforts:

  1. Contribute to this Indiegogo campaign.

  2. Make a direct contribution to the PS:Fishbowl located at the gallery.

  3. Spread the word to Save PS:Gallery to everyone you know.

 

PS:Perks

Here are just a few samples of the amazing incentives that will be given back to you as PS:Gallery advocates. And be sure to visit our page daily! We'll be refreshing the perks on a regular basis throughout the course of the campaign.

AVAILABLE AT THE $50 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

AVAILABLE AT THE $50 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

AVAILABLE EVERY LEVEL AT OR ABOVE 10% OF YOUR CONTRIBUTION.  WHO DOESN'T LOVE ICE CREAM?!

1- Complete photo set (3 original 11"x14" giclées, signed matte boards included) by Katie Barnes 

AVAILABLE AT THE $200 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

 

 

 

1 example of 10 Original Watercolor Landscapes by Mark Grundy, 10"x13" unframed

AVAILABLE AT THE $250 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL 

 

Orginal Laura Lloyd portraits (Group 1)- 6"x6" oil painting on board

AVAILABLE AT THE $250 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

 

Orginal Laura Lloyd portraits (Group 2) - 6"x6" oil painting on board

AVAILABLE AT THE $350 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

 

Original Design Necklace by Jewelry Artist, Pam Caidin - fine sterling silver, 14k yellow gold

AVAILABLE AT THE $350 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL 

 

Signed Original by Mike Sleadd -  11"x14" Pen and Ink Unframed

AVAILABLE AT THE $500 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

 

Original Glicee by Notely Hawkins - 25"x33" Framed

AVAILABLE AT THE $550 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

Original Design Necklace by Jewelry Artist, Kenny Greene, Moss Agate Sterling Silver

AVAILABLE AT THE $550 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL 

 

2 Original Paintings by Nora Othic - Pastel 21"x25" &  Oil 18"x18" Natural Wood Frames

AVAILABLE AT THE $700 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

 

 

Original Design Necklace and Earring Set by Jewelry Artist, Casey Sheppard 

AVAILABLE AT THE $750 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL 

 

 

"Rural Structure VII" Original Framed Collage, Roofing Tar, and Oil Painting by Joel Sager

AVAILABLE AT THE $2000 CONTRIBUTION LEVEL

 

 

PS:Transparency

Funds for this Indiegogo campaign will directly aid:

  1. Promotional marketing for the gallery as well as each artist we represent for 1 year 
  2. Transition expenses of the gallery's ownership 
  3. Operational costs including reception expenses for both artists and hosted not-for-profits
  4. Advancement in marketing and visibility of the gallery as a national arts destination

story:
- Hello!  My name is Rae Vena, I am 24 year old traveler,  Visionary surrealist painter. and freelance artist  from Cleveland Ohio.   www.facebook.com/RAEVENAartist

 I have traveled to share my live art performance with over 50 festivals nationwide.  Ive been invited to bring my Live art performance & gallery to over 10 festivals again this summer!   Link to my Tour Lineup 2013!==>https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=606055079405639&set=a.138094266201725.23613.125252150819270&type=1&theater

The Purpose of this project: 

 Together. with the support of my family, & friends I plan to acquire professional supplies for a new comfortable gallery, that I can safely exhibit my newest paintings !

Break down of the budget for the Live art gallery:

1  heavy duty, waterproof, UV resistant tent with weights & sidewalls-  $300

1 super heavy duty tarp, metal stakes, extra tools and rope- $70

Drapes, candles, flowers, and other decor- $100

1 large weather resistant outdoor rug, and pillows for seating- $250

6 Giclee canvas prints of my larger paintings for the gallery -$400                 

1  Sturdy , portable wooden easel that can hold BIG paintings- $120                      

30 Giclee paper prints- $300

1 lightweight foldable print basket- $50        

Gas and travel expenses for my 2013 art tour- $800                                     

50 tree spruclings for planting in Ohio to carbon offset my 2012 Live art tour- $39

50 trees donated to Arbor day foundation to plant in National forests- $50

___________________________________________________________________________________  *additional funds will help pay for supplies to paint my new gallery & van mural!

  As a backer of my project you are my official sponsor of VISION QUEST:: Live art tour 2013 and directly supporting my artistic growth & professional development. There are not enough words to express the love & passion that follows my work. With my new gallery I plan to branch out further in the art world and share my vision to inspire friends for many years to come!    

Every donation over $70 will have tree planted in a National Forest in their name! and will recieve a special card of thank you<3

 

 Every supporter will receive a beautiful package of rainbow art! Along with a  handwritten letter of my gratitude for your contribution ___________________________

 $5-  BLISS CAT + one!  : Ill send you in the mail a sticker of my painting "Bliss cat" 4x5.5"    and a surprise sticker! 

                    

$15 - Rainbow Surprise! :: A 10 x10" poster print of "Pura Vida en Costa Rica!",  

                                                        ...and a surprise sticker!  

     

 

$25 - 13 Stickers of Art! :: My brand new 13 piece Sticker pack featuring all  my best paintings! This set includes ALL of the stickers shown above, and below. For my project- this special edition Sticker pack  also comes with a hand- painted magnet!

    

 

$35-  Patch , Pack  :: 1 Hand painted patch,  and my 13 piece Sticker pack!

 

$45-Vision Quest Painted Sketch! ::    A 4 by 5 inch or larger original painted sketch from inspiration on my Vision Quest!  I will also mail you my brand new Special edition  13 piece sticker pack with a hand painted magnet!                      

  

 

$50-  Fine Art Print // Sticker Pack :: A matted 8 x 10" Archival Giclee print of the painting of your choice, and my 13 piece Sticker pack with a hand-painted magnet!                                       Email me for larger photos of your print choices!  -artist@raevena.com

   

 $60- Vision Quest Choice Combo :: A framed  8 x 10 " painted sketch made during my VISION QUEST :: Live art tour 2013 , A 10x10" poster print of "Pura Vida en Costa Rica!", and my 13 piece Sticker pack!               

                   

 

 $77- **Mystery art box** -a Treasure chest from my VISION QUEST!               

       Not actual Mystery art box shown- Because each one will be unique!  

 

 $101- The Art Collector ::  A Super combo pack to decorate your life- a framed  8 x 10 " painted sketch made during my VISION QUEST :: Live art tour 2013,  A painted patch , A 10x10" poster print of "Pura Vida en Costa Rica!",  my Special Edition- 13 piece Sticker pack , And a matted- 8 x 10" Archival Giclee print of the painting of your choice!  

Photos of Giclee print choices available  email me-   artist@raevena.com          

 

$123- A Gift for the Girls :: An  upcycled- hand bag, custom hand painted with your favorite colors! and my Special Edition -13 piece Sticker set. Shown here are the 3 choices of upcycled hand bags.                         

            

 

 $222- Super Sponsor :: As one of my official sponsors you have your pick of one large- 16 x 20 inch -Framed Archival Giclee Canvas print of the painting of your choice! (Each of my Giclee canvas prints are a Limited edition of 100 - signed, and numbered!) , I will also send you one- 8x 10"  Original, framed painted sketch made during my VISION QUEST:: Live art tour 2013, and my  Special Edition- 13 piece Sticker pack.! 

Larger Photos of print choices available. email ::artist@raevena.com

 

$333+ Official Sponsor ::This is a negotiable perk level, for those interested in owning large Original works of art by Rae Vena- visual artist . Prices range from $333 and up. Serious inquiries only.

Contact me if you have any questions or for more Info at ::  artist@raevena.com

           

  •    ‘Visionary Pop Surrealism’ is one way to describe the paintings I improvise live -in front of the audience.  The artwork shown in my gallery above are all Inspired by Live music and atmosphere! - My art is a moving , ever changing  installation on an easel! I have traveled to over 50 music festivals across the nation to bring live art performance to the people. My vision of colorful, organic shapes and forms.. I  create to express the ever evolving beauty in nature..

    I paint a picture of positivity and I can give back love and creativity into my community

     

Last summer we saw some wicked weather that destroyed alot of my equipment and even..... original artwork.   

  So For this season-  I am asking for your help to start this year with something  professional, sturdy and fresh for the festivals and create a Live art gallery that is a welcoming  and safe space  to feature my art.   With the support for my new art space, I want to inspire my new friends to come in - sit back, and relax with me, and check out my newest paintings!   :)    

 

  • Other Ways You Can Help ::

I understand that I'm not the only one with money problems.. so if you can't donate financially, consider donating a few minutes of your time instead to help my project gain some exposure!   

Share my project with your friends on your facebook & twitter!

  Thank you for taking the time to check out my project! 

Ill be posting more information on my upcoming tour dates on my facebook art page- www.facebook.com/RAEVENAartist

Thank you for helping me share my vision <3

                                          

much Love, Rae Vena

 follow my art page for info updates and tour photos of my art gallery! www.facebook.com/RAEVENAartist

   ‘Visionary Pop Surrealism’ is one way to describe the paintings I improvise live -in front of the audience.  The artwork shown in my gallery above are all Inspired by Live music and atmosphere! - My art is a moving , ever changing  installation on an easel! I have traveled to over 50 music festivals across the nation to bring live art performance to the people. My vision of colorful, organic shapes and forms.. I  create to express the ever evolving beauty in nature..
I paint a picture of positivity and I can give back love and creativity into my community
 

Last summer we saw some wicked weather that destroyed alot of my equipment and even..... original artwork.    
  So For this season-  I am asking for your help to start this year with something  professional, sturdy and fresh for the festivals and create a Live art gallery that is a welcoming  and safe space  to feature my art.   With the support for my new art space, I want to inspire my new friends to come in - sit back, and relax with me, and check out my newest paintings!   :)    
 


Other Ways You Can Help ::


I understand that I'm not the only one with money problems.. so if you can't donate financially, consider donating a few minutes of your time instead to help my project gain some exposure!   
Share my project with your friends on your facebook & twitter!

  Thank you for taking the time to check out my project! 
Ill be posting more information on my upcoming tour dates on my facebook art page- www.facebook.com/RAEVENAartist
Thank you for helping me share my vision <3
                                           

much Love, Rae Vena
 follow my art page for info updates and tour photos of my art gallery! www.facebook.com/RAEVENAartist

story:
Entropy is a collaboration between choreographer/vocalist Alicia Mullikin, and multi-Instrumentalist Daniel Mullikin. Their first evening length work, Iron Daisies, will be presented at Velocity Dance Center on October 18th & 19th, 2013. Their interest is in exploring the capacity of movement and sound through various artistic mediums. Entropy blurs the line between dance and accompaniment by directly incorporating the musician and vocalizations into the choreography. Their underlying idea is to create and develop their work in full view of the audience every time it is performed. This requires not only rehearsal time for movement and sound, but also time to gain familiarity with the technical aspects of the work such as the use of microphones, loop pedals, effects, and various electronics. The electronics are used not only as a tool for accompaniment, but as another form of expression for both the musician and dancers. The music and dance equally initiate one another throughout this process. Set choreography is manipulated and moved through cues in the sound which are also created live by each performer. Entropy will often explore their relationship with the audience through verbal or physical engagement. These aspects of the work make each performance unique. Through this collaborative process Entropy is able to create work that challenges the boundaries between dancer and musician, as well as audience and performer. Please help support Entropy's first evening length piece.

 Spreading the word is just as important. If you are unable to contribute monitarily, you can pass the info along and spread the news about this exciting new project. Every contribution goes directly into the creation of this work. Thank you sincerely for all of your generosity and support, and we hope to see you at the premier of Iron Daisies on October 18th and 19th at Velocity Dance Center.

 

WHERE YOUR CONTRIBUTION IS GOING:

$700 Performance Venue

$400 Rehearsal Space Rental (4 months)

$300 Tech Gear/ Electronics essential to the work

$300 Technical Crew

$250 Dancer stipend (4 dancers)

$100 House Management

$100 Costumes

$50 Publicity Materials

$50 Tech/Dress Rehearsal Space Rental

 

COLLABORATORS:

 Choreography/Vocals: Alicia Mullikin

 Music/Live Sound Engineer: Daniel Mullikin

 Dancer/Vocals:

 Danica Bito

 Alyza DelPan Monley

 Margaret Hotchkiss

 Carla Maria Negrete Martinez

 

For more info on Entropy visit:  Facebook.com/EntropyPerformance

story:
Using Art to Defend Israel and Syria from Assad's Chemical Weapons

Artists 4 Israel's Art Over War unites international artists to provide relief for those suffering from Syria's bloody civil war and to protect Israel from impending rocket attacks. 

A4I is most well known for bringing global artists to paint the bomb shelters of Sderot. In that small city, on the border of the Gaza Strip, we learned the power that art has to heal the trauma of war and to bring international attention to a serious issue. We still are in touch with the children who cried and thanked us and the families that met us at every bomb shelter to thank us.

Now, we are committed, even in the most dangerous situation imaginable to bring the same hope through art to the Golan Heights, the site of current attacks from Assad and the rebel fighters. 

Our artists are afraid, especially since there were two attacks in the very area yesterday, but we will not let that stop us!

Every Single Dollar Goes to Buying Paint

Artists 4 Israel has funded almost every part of this trip through direct donations. All that is left is the need for the spray paint to create our giant murals. Paint costs between $8 and $10 a can. We will be using over 1,000 cans. If we can raise $5,000, we are halfway there. Even if we don't reach the 5,000, all the money STILL goes to buying spray paint. It is that direct.

The Children of Sderot

Please google Artists 4 Israel's MURALITY project, Sderot, to see some of what we have done in the past.

story:
NO ARTIST IS LOST, WHEN TODAY’S ARTISTS REMEMBER


During the late 1980s, West Hollywood was a hotbed of cultural experimentation around video, performance, and digital art. The independent video space EZTV, then located on Santa Monica Boulevard, was an epicenter for creativity across a range of new media. 

Fiercely independent, this group of artists, including pioneering digital artists, dared to experiment in a medium so new that it was yet to be accepted in the mainstream art establishment. In the past, art institutions have often over-looked the transformative cultural contributions made through the experiments conceived by a small group of digital artists and their collaborating engineers and other creative thinkers. Today’s now ubiquitous use of new media, in everything from the visual, sound, and performing arts, owes much to the contributions made these artists.

The celebrate this rich yet under-recognized history, EZTV, LA ACM SIGGRAPH, ONE National Gay & Lesbian Archives, and the City of West Hollywood will present a free public art event to draw public attention to these pioneering artists and the spaces and organizations that’s supported their work, as well as those who follow in their footsteps. We hope that you will join us and help light up a community and its history.  


About ONE Night

For one night, an exciting collaboration of artists and thinkers will come together to stage a free, immersive art event on May 31, 2014 in the West Hollywood Park. ONE Night: EZTV, LA ACM SIGGRAPH, and Digital Art in West Hollywood brings together four unique organizations seeking to draw attention to the rich history of digital art in Southern California: EZTV, an artist run video space and one of the first arts organizations to curate and show digital art; LA ACM SIGGRAPH, the foremost association for computer graphics and interactive technologies; ONE National Gay & Lesbian Archives, the largest LGBTQ archive in the world; and the City of West Hollywood.

In addition to numerous large-scale projections, the event will include live music, dance, telematics, and multimedia performances. Both a retrospective of pioneering digital artists and a showcase of contemporary practitioners, through projections onto both buildings and an aerial inflatable, the event will transform the parkgrounds into an evening-long experiential and multi-faceted media installation.

ONE Night coincides with the conclusion of the three-month long exhibition EZTV: Video Transfer at ONE Archives Gallery & Museum. While ONE Night focuses on EZTV’s contributions to digital art history, EZTV: Video Transfer explores EZTV’s equally important early role in the fostering and presenting of queer video.

ONE Nights will highlight the contributions of a generation of forward thinking artists who helped birth a new art form. Digital art pioneers, they created some of the first digital images to be projected for site specific and large-scale live art events.


The Artists

One such artist, Ron Hays, was the foremost pioneer of the field during the 1980s. An Emmy Award winning director, Hays created projections using a combination of digital synthesizers, animation, and dance to visualize music for everyone from Frank Gehry, the experimental WNET television lab pieces along with artist Nam June Paik, to the Boston and Los Angeles Philharmonic Symphonies. Like many of the innovative and now almost forgotten queer artists who worked with EZTV, Hays died of AIDS at the height of his career and at the age of 45.  


Still from Ron Hays' Odyssey, 1979. EZTV Video Collection.
ONE Archives at the USC Libraries
ONE Night is inspired by an earlier projection event organized by Hays and digital artist Joan Collins in March 1988 to celebrate the opening of the Green Building at the Pacific Design Center. The event, Sky Work, similarly included a large inflatable balloon onto which intricate digital projections were displayed.

ONE Night also draws special attention to the important role women played in developing the creative tools and visual vocabularies in digital technologies now taken for granted. The event will include works by Rebecca Allen, founding chair of the Design Department/Media Arts at UCLA who has been exhibited at the Centre Pompidou (Paris), and the Whitney Museum of American Art (New York); Vibeke Sorensen, Professor and Chair of the Department of Visual Arts at Nanyang Technical University, Singapore; and Shelley Lake, the first woman to graduate from the MIT Media Lab.

Both internationally recognized producers and equally significant yet over-looked artists from the late 1970s and 80s will be included in ONE Night. Highlighting the contributions made by these under-represented producers and groups is a key part of the purpose of this ambitious outdoor exhibition.


Digital Artist Rebecca Allen's studio, c. 1980s. Courtesy of EZTV


The West Hollywood sign is unveiled outside EZTV on April 15, 1986. Sallie M. Fiske Papers and Photographs. ONE Archives at the USC Libraries


A City Park Transformed

Framed by the architecture of the Pacific Design Center in the background, ONE Night will include a 45-foot tall video projection onto the West Hollywood Library and projections onto a spherical inflatable suspended in the air above the West Hollywood Park. Between these two projections will be performances throughout the evening, including the premiere of Fly-By by Donna Sternberg & Dancers. Sternberg’s live site-specific dancers will perform in real time with projections of dancer/avatars being performed by Vanessa Blaylock & Co in The Hague, accompanyed by original music by composer David Raiklen.

Oscar-winning sound artist Frank Serafine will play live accompaniment to recently re-discovered Ron Hays’ video projections. The evening will conclude with a performance by artist/musician Kate Crash, LA Weekly’s favorite "collision of art and music."

Transforming an urban park into a large scale art installation and performance space will require renting high powered HD theater grade projectors, generators, servers, sound equipment, and technical support. This is why we are seeking your support. 


Still from Dave Curlender and David Goodsell's Larger Than Life, 1985.
Courtesy of the artists
 

How Can You Help Make This Happen

With your help, this evening can bring a visually stunning, immersive, and engaging art experience free to the public. It will also begin a discussion of the important contributions to the field by artists who dared to work with new mediums, giving voice to new methods of expression, and, for some, have yet to be included in the official histories.The City of West Hollywood has generously contributed both funds to realize this ambitious program and access to public facilities; however, additional support is needed to realize the project as envisioned. That is why we are reaching out to the greater community to help in bringing attention to this rich history widely unknown to the public.

We need an additional $10,000.00. If we raise more we will be able to expand the project reach and pay artists. Your donation to this public art event will also be tax deductible.

The funding will help us:

  • Rent two powerful 20k lumens projectors with media servers.
  • Pay technical crew and transportation.
  • Rent a three phase power generator and distribution.
  • Rent a sound system for performances.


The Impact

This project brings a community together to celebrate the history of digital art and the significant contributions made by women, LGBTQ individuals, and other under-recognized communities of artists. These early practitioners and advocates for today’s now ubiquitous media arts revolution have been often-overlooked. ONE Night seeks to remedy these over-sights.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute funds, but would like to help the project, here are some other ways to get involved:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about ONE Night. Share the campaign via social media and tell your friends!
  • We need volunteers. If you are interested in volunteering the day of the event, please email eztv@eztvmedia.com.
  • If you have access to equipment that you can share for the event, we'd like to hear from you. Please email us at eztv@eztvmedia.com if you think you have the advanced projection equipment needed for such an ambitious program.


Thank You

Many thanks for considering funding this project. Your support is deeply appreciated as donations from generous people like you help make it possible for artists to create work, share stories, performances, and music and to remember our shared legacies. Thank you.


Still from Vibeke Sorensen’s NLOOPS, 1987-88. NTSC color video, 7 minutes. Courtesy of the artist


ONE Night Video: 
Artists in order of Appearance

  • Artist Rendering of event featuring Ron Hays (left) and Dave Curlender & David Goodsell (right)
  • Ron Hays
  • Dave Curlender & David Goodsell
  • Rebecca Allen
  • Kate Johnson
  • Michael Masucci: West Hollywood Sign
  • Victor Acevedo
  • Rebecca Allen
  • Vibeke Sorensen
  • Frank Serafine
  • Donna Sternberg & Dancers
  • Kate Crash
  • Kate Johnson
  • Rebecca Allen
  • Ed Emshwiller
  • Shelley Lake

story:
What it's for:

I'm a visual artist working with photography and organic processes. I and am hungry to learn and develop my practise. 

Thanks to your generous support so far, I have been able to attend the photography course at Dartmoor Arts Summer School, the content of which built on the concerns and approaches that I explore as part of my practise. It has been a phenomenal experience full of learning, inspiration and confidence building.

I now need your help to reach the target so that I can pay off the balance for the course.

More about the course:

Photo Work : 5 Approaches to Contemporary Photography at Dartmoor Arts

Five different approaches to photographic image making over the course of five days by five different practitioners, each known for their work in a particular area of contemporary art photography.

The course explored how these approaches to working within a natural environment parallel developments in the history of photography, from the early explorations of Fox Talbot and Anna Aitkins with cyanotypes and direct sun print methods, through to the opening up of space with pinhole and lens based cameras and camera obscuras, to a focus on place, the observation of natural phenomena and projection of memory and internal narratives that form the content of much contemporary photography.

The course program began with an introduction by Susan Derges, and included 5 extraordinary days of workshops by 5 experts in their fields: 

Liz Nicol: cyanotypes

Sian Bonnell: pinhole

Tom Hunter: a performative approach with large format pinhole

Jem Southam: a painterly approach with large format (and ladder) 

Chrystel Lebas: twilight photography

The evenings included talks, debates, performance and meeting amazing people


I WILL BE WRITING MORE ABOUT THE EXPERIENCE ON MY BLOG!


Where will the money go:

  • 540: Cost of the course including material £540 
  • £20: Portfolio review with Susan Derges
  • £80: Travel
  • £105: Bunk accommodation
  • £150: post course production cost
  • £26: (estimate to make it a nice looking £1001 for Indiegogo Fees)

And now for...


THE PERKS:

The Perks are listed along the right-hand side and you will find a representational visual below.  You will find further descriptions at the bottom of this page.

A big thank you & my eternal gratitude!

featuring an Anthotype of your choice, including envelope;
+ a personal invite to my Open Studio in October;
